story:
We are the Woolly Production Team, students who work in team to strive for an accomplished film. This project is called “Sheared Happiness” and it is about a sheep who ventures for love. This campaign is crucial for this project because it will help drive the film forward, it will help us get the help and support from everyone.  

We need $1500 to fund for our animation. The funding will go towards the venue to screen our animation, posters, and entering film festivals. We are a team of happiness and full with joy. We laugh, we cry, and we cherish each other like a family. We use gags and jokes for entertainment to keep our spirit lively. We have a strong passion to fight each war and to tackle obstacles. However, the funding will still go towards our priority if all things failed.

Obstacles will be a bumpy road and everything will be a crying storm, but that will not stop us from achieving our goals. Our plan is to have a backup plan, external route, to solve problem, find options, and to take risks if no option is available.  

Thank you for contributing and supporting us! Please help share our website, projects, and spread the word around by clicking the Indiegogo share tool!

story:
Who Am I? 

Oh hi there! My name is Myra Flynn. I'm an indie/soul singer-songwriter and there are three crucial things I've learned about working in music: 

1.) Being talented is only part of the job. 

2.) Travel, work and record until you think you can't travel, work and record anymore then travel, work and record some more. 

3.) Recognize when your small business has reached a level of success as high as you can possibly reach on your own...then ask those who have supported you to carry it further. 

So: let's try this again. Hi, My name is Myra Flynn. I'm and indie/soul singer-songwriter hailing from Vermont (go figure?) and have been toggling between New York City, my home state and now Los Angeles for nearly ten years now. I recorded an album, made one music video, traveled from state to state on self-made tours, started a private teaching practice, won a couple music awards, started a jewelry line, recorded another album, wrote for Universal Records, made a third album, signed a licensing deal, moved to Australia, moved back to Los Angeles, met my management team, signed with my management team, recorded my fourth body of work and here we are. 

I won an award once and the title was "Myra Flynn: The Hardest Working Woman in Showbiz." I think at that time I was flattered that my efforts were being recognized, after all: everyone from Vermont works like a farmer. However in these last few years I've learned that it's time to stop looking at my small business as shoveling snow, chopping wood and planting gardens. The garden is in and it's blossomed and thankfully, fruitful. It's time to work smarter not harder and to also recognize that things are in place right now for me to go pretty far in this business. In short, the adverb for my small business has gone from "what" to..."how"? 

That's where you come in: Number 3 on my list of things I've learned. I have been lucky enough to work with a management team of two who also work like farmers, for me! In the last two years since adding Los Angeles to my lexicon they have made it possible for me to: record an album’s worth of music with a multitude of producers including Grammy Award-winning rockstar Jared Lee Gosselin (http://www.jaredleegosselin.com/) and an all-star team of up and coming producers The Classmatez (https://theclassmatez.bandpage.com/)   as well as film my second music video to a hit single "Nobody's Business" featuring Barbadian reggae superstar Rayvon (https://youtu.be/XWJrPzAUzAs). The coolest part? Most of the people involved in my projects have worked hard to help me out of the goodness of their own hearts and total belief in my rise to stardom. (I can't believe that's a real sentence for me right now?!). I'm just incredibly grateful for the efforts and support they have shown me. So grateful in fact that I want to make sure I "do right" by these awesome creations and by that I mean I want to get our music and brand out into the world in a way I never have before. I can't do more of the same, so I need your help getting myself, my small business, my music and my team to The Next Level.

Where Your Money Is Going

My team and I believe we've figured out the best plan of action for our project. If you're wondering...yes, record labels have shown interest. But in reality, record labels are mostly interested in the buzz you have created on your own. And if I decide not to sign and continue to remain independent, well, then at least I've got buzz. :) So what does it take to create a solid underground buzz? Check it out. 

Digital Promotion

$10,000 

 DP is basically a working machine of individuals who use one or more forms of electronic media (SoundCloud, YouTube etc...) to market or advertise my brand. With their help, I can increase visibility and number of clicks for my music and video which is crucial because in a day and age where the Internet is clogged with many, this is how you stand out.  This team of people will also work to put my music and video in clubs, stores, on airplanes, on the radio, in DJ's hands and so much more! I could be everywhere! ( Insert creepy laugh). 


Public Relations (PR)

$10,000

PR is a whole other machine of people who are in charge of the way we will communicate with the public and media. A PR specialist communicates with the target audience directly or indirectly through media with an aim to create and maintain a positive image and create a strong relationship with the audience. They will do much of what Digital Promotion will do but also in the print and person to person world. They will help you secure premieres of songs and videos on cool, high-traffic blogs and help me get interviews and other press pieces. They will upgrade my life!!! Like, seriously, upgrade, organize and demand the best of me as a brand and communicate the most polished version of it all to the world. (Because not everyone wakes up like Beyonce, am I right?). 

Merchandise

$2,000

I have never once, in the entirety of my career, had the extra funds to go the extra mile, to make things like T-shirts and tote bags. But you know what? NO MORE! No longer will you walk the streets of life without my name and face on the front of your chest. No longer will you use a plastic bag at the grocery store--no-- your organic kale will go into an environmentally friendly Myra Flynn tote bag. And you should accept nothing less! Secretly, I'm hoping that we raise even a little more than our intended goal here so I can print more of these archaic things we call "CDs". Even if you'd rather use them as a table leveler or a coaster....I still think they're awesome and apparently so do my fans because I’m sold out. 


Mixing and Mastering 

$,5000

At the moment, the plan for this new music is to release the songs as individual singles paired with a music video and a whole bunch of press surrounding each one. Here is where all of that can go horribly wrong: If the music does not sound up to snuff. Basically, mixing is the step before mastering that involves adjusting and combining individual tracks together to form a stereo audio file after mixdown. The stereo file is then mastered, which ensures that the various songs are clearly polished and form a cohesive whole on an album. In short: this necessary process makes your music sound good. So, yeah. That has to happen. 

The Impact

So many of you reading this have been supporting me since I was a young girl doing talent shows and singing wildly off key. Some of you are new to me as an artist and that's wonderful, too. Either way I'd say that now is a good time for me to be doing this. In fact, I think it's an ideal time. My half African American, half Irish voice has been compared to some pretty awesome women like Joan Armatrading and Annie Lennox, voices that up until recently have been associated with a throwback sound. But we are in a pretty cool time right now because hit artists like Adele, Sam Smith, Alessia Cara and Lianne La Havas (to name a few) are sweeping the world and in my opinion, upgrading our sound to one that is racially ambiguous, futuristic and absolutely fascinating. Your help will elevate my career to a place where it belongs: up there with the rest of the musical weirdos. And I'm proud to be one! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you might be hustling through your own art project right now and cannot contribute financially. Believe me when I tell you: I totally get it. But you can still help the cause by making a racket about my campaign. Indiegogo is actually awesome about helping you do that easily. Here's how: 

  • Copy the campaign URL and paste it into an email or social media update
  • Click on the Facebook, Google Plus or Twitter icons to share through your social media networks
  • Add a widget to your blog or personal website. Click Embed and then copy and paste the widget code. 

And that's all folks. I hope to make you swell with pride when you see how we will put your contributions to great use. I will see you on the other side of awesome. 

xoxo

story:
OVERVIEW

Each winter on the Green in New Haven, CT, several religious organizations display holiday symbols. But while many people enjoy their light and beauty, something is missing: A nonreligious symbol celebrating universal human values that can resonate with all people.

The Green Light Project will bring a gift of a sculpture to the community, from the community, to be displayed on the Green during the coldest, darkest months of the year. It will complement the menorah, nativity, and Christmas tree but represent the warmth and hope of all humanity without regard to religion. This interactive light sculpture—conceived and coordinated by the Yale Humanist Community (YHC), a nonprofit organization that is open to everyone and supports an ethical, compassionate approach to life—will represent the goodwill of our community and celebrate the unique diversity of each individual who contributes to making our community so vibrant.

YHC has commissioned Edwin “Ted” Salmon to create this symbol of the human spirit in community. This original, interactive sculpture will enhance the luster of the seasonal display on the Green, create a focal point for congregation and connection, and express our commitment to the well-being of the people who inhabit our city, nation and world. Its annual presence will serve as an inclusive, welcoming reminder that when people of all beliefs and backgrounds come together, we can create beauty, light, and warmth during even the coldest and darkest time of the year.

Salmon’s concept of an obelisk—reminiscent of a lighthouse and adorned with silhouette images representing various facets of community—will stand 15 feet high and be visible from all sides of the Green. As individuals gather near, the light will change and grow warmer. Once enough people surround the sculpture the light will begin to pulse like a heartbeat, reminding us of our shared humanity.

Perhaps the most exciting part of this sculpture is that it will house a time capsule containing thousands of words of wisdom for humanity contributed by community members. It will be opened in honor of the 500th anniversary of the City of New Haven in the year 2138, connecting community across time. What do you love about the Greater New Haven area, or any part of the world? What wisdom would you want to preserve for future generations? There’s so much in our amazing local and global community that makes life deeply meaningful; what reflection would you share with the community of the future?  

Learn more about the time capsule: 


Time capsule contributors are also invited to include optional identifying information, such as a birthdate, so that their future relatives might recognize their message when displayed in 2138. These messages will also be sealed and stored electronically in collaboration with the New Haven Museum to ensure their survival.

We’ve launched this IndieGOGO campaign to raise the funds to pay for this ambitious work of art. Our backer rewards offer a number of amazing ways to contribute both words of wisdom and objects into the time capsule, as well as many other great perks. We are offering a GLP pin and miniature green lights. Larger rewards include the chance to have your name included on the sculpture with an acknowledgment plaque or, even better, an inscription that will last as long as the sculpture does. You'll even have the opportunity to receive a two-foot replica of the Green Light installation. 

   

Wear your support for the Green Light Project with this exclusive enamel pin. Designed by a New Haven artist, this pin is both a take on the GLP logo and evocative of the New Haven Green, featuring design elements inspired by an aerial view of the Green. And, like the sculpture you're helping us create, this pin will glow in the dark! This pin is included in all perks $50 and up. 
In celebration of our campaign, we’re having a number of events to spread the word. See the list of events below where you can learn more about the Green Light Project in person. 

Approximately 24% of the U.S. population does not identify as religious (Pew Research, 2015). It’s not hard for some to feel disenfranchised from the heart of our community, the town Green, during the holiday season when religious symbolism is so prominent. The Green Light Project offers a respectful, beautiful new tradition to the Greater New Haven community that relates to 100% of our neighbors, friends, co-workers and visitors. Your financial help—anything you can contribute—is crucial to bringing the project to fruition. Please help us bring this illuminating new tradition to the New Haven Green and, through the time capsule, join us in offering our collective expressions of hope, warmth, and goodwill to all.

Check out what local religious leaders had to say about our concept: 


ABOUT THE SPONSORING ORGANIZATION

The Yale Humanist Community is a 501(c)(3) non-profit dedicated to supporting a diverse nonreligious community at Yale and beyond. Many YHC events are open to the public, including Humanist Haven, a bi-monthly gathering featuring a wide array of thought-provoking speakers. Visit yalehumanists.com to learn more. The Yale Humanist Community is an affiliate of the American Humanist Association.

ABOUT THE ARTIST

Edwin “Ted” Salmon has lived and worked throughout the country, and has showcased his work continuously for over 25 years. A sculptor by trade, he educated himself on metal fabrication and eventually opened up his own company EWS3D LLC. Notable works include a piece in Ellison Center for the Arts’ permanent collection in Duxbury, Massachusetts, a large outdoor sculpture for Marriott’s Fairfield Residence Inn in Downtown Brooklyn. Locally, Ted and his team have worked with Geronimo, Shell and Bones and many others. His firm has also done architectural work for Yale, Quinnipiac University, Starbucks and Subway.

RISKS

The basic sculpture with no interactive lighting, and necessary administrative expenses to support it such as City and Proprietors of the Green coordination, will cost approximately $40,000. If we can’t raise enough money to make that goal, there’s a possibility that the timeline for this project will be pushed back until 2017. This would be extremely unfortunate since we have all the resources in place to make this project happen now. We have many commitments from organizations and individuals around New Haven who support the project’s overall mission of creating universal light and warmth for the entire community.



ACKNOWLEDGMENTS 

Video by: Mike Rhodes

Photographs in video courtesy of:

Dan Mims / dailynutmeg.com

New Haven Register

story:
Des créations uniques et artisanales!

Machii se manifeste à travers des créations organiques et naturelles, nous invitant à redécouvrir une éthique juste et sensible par des vêtements  sans produits chimiques qui respectent l'équilibre naturel du corps, et dont les tissus proviennent d'une agriculture écologique et respectueuse. Profondément marquée par un chemin à travers la danse et le voyage, les vêtements de Machii d'adaptent aux formes naturelles du corps permettant un maximum de confort et de fluidité de mouvements. 

 

Fibres naturelles et conscience écologique

L'utilisation de tissus naturels est l'aspect le plus important d'une recherche sur la manière dont nous pouvons interagir avec la nature qui nous entoure. Machii choisis d'abord de travailler à partir de tissus naturels tels que le chanvre, celui-ci étant naturellement écologique, par sa propriété de régénérer la terre où il pousse. En respectant la nature nous respectons également notre corps, à travers des vêtements naturels qui le laissent respirer et protègent notre peau. 

Machii aime les vêtements confortables, que l'on peut porter en toute occasion. C'est pourquoi le chanvre est souvent mélangé à du coton de jersey qui lui donne une certaine élasticité, et un retombé fluide qui se laisse danser, bouger, respirer ! Machii aime que vous puissiez vous sentir confortable dans vos vêtements tout en restant féminine et élégante!


 Financement d'une surjetteuse/surfileuse

Le jersey étant une fibre difficile à coudre avec une simple machine, il est aujourd'hui plus que nécessaire d'acquérir une surjeteuse/surfileuse professionnelle. Le jersey est un tissu qui se détend très facilement, hors avec une surfileuse le tissu peut être cousu sans se déformer. L'acquisition de cette surfileuse offre des possibilités qu'une machine normale ne peut pas offrir, et ouvre la porte à une créativité qui donne libre cours à des modèles toujours plus confortables  et élégants. Une surjetteuse permettra également d'améliorer la qualité des  finitions, ainsi que la durabilité et solidité des coutures, pour des créations que vous porterez encore plus longtemps! 


La surfileuse en question est une surfileuse de marque JUKI, MO-654DE.


Pourquoi contribuer à ce projet? 

Actuellement, n'ayant pas d'autres possibilités en Belgique, je paie 70 à 80 % de taxes, et il est encore aujourd'hui difficile pour moi d'obtenir les fonds nécessaires à l'achat d'une surfileuse professionnelle. C'est pourquoi je fais appel à vous, sachant que même la plus petite aide d'1, 2, 5, 10, 20 euros sera utile à la création d'une marque de vêtements fabriqués localement, qui respectent le corps et l'environnement, en proposant une alternative concrète à la pollution des sols, conscéquences directes de l'industrie du textile. Il me tient particulièrement à coeur de proposer des créations textiles sans produit chimiques qui n'entreront pas en interaction avec votre corps. Je m'applique à trouver des tissus naturels autant que possible en provenance d'une agriculture biologique et respectueuse de l'environnement ou la fibre a été cultivée. Il est également très important pour moi que mes créations puissent être portées de façon à se sentir bien dans son corps (et dans sa tête ! ) tout en apportant une touche d'élégance, de simplicité et de confort, d'où l'utilisation du chanvre et coton de jersey, qui permet cet élasticité et ce confort dans les mouvements. 


 Où me trouver et comment aider ? 

Actuellement, je travaille dans mon propre petit atelier à Bruxelles.

Si vous souhaitez connaître la démarche de Machii plus en profondeur, je vous invite à découvrir mon site web : www.machii.be

Vous avez également la possibilité de suivre les créations de Machii via facebook : https://www.facebook.com/machiipachamama/

Egalement via ma boutique en ligne : https://www.alittlemarket.com/boutique/machii-3049.html


Vous pouvez contribuer à ce projet en apportant une aide financière via indiegogo, ainsi qu'en partageant autour de vous. Le montant de votre don est libre, vous donnez absolument ce que vous voulez. Les montants fixes proposés vous offre une contrepartie en retour. 


Amicalement et avec toute ma gratitude, 


Machii
story_txt:
Des créations uniques et artisanales!





Machii se
manifeste à travers des créations organiques
et naturelles,
nous invitant à redécouvrir une éthique juste
et sensible par des vêtements  sans produits chimiques qui
respectent l'équilibre naturel du corps, et dont les tissus
proviennent d'une agriculture écologique et
respectueuse. Profondément marquée par un chemin à travers
la danse et le voyage, les vêtements de Machii
d'adaptent aux formes naturelles du corps permettant un maximum
de confort et de fluidité de mouvements. 




 

Fibres
naturelles et conscience écologique



L'utilisation
de tissus naturels est l'aspect le plus important d'une recherche sur
la manière dont nous pouvons interagir avec la nature qui nous
entoure. Machii choisis
d'abord de travailler à partir de tissus naturels tels que
le chanvre,
celui-ci étant naturellement écologique, par sa propriété de
régénérer la terre où il pousse. En respectant la
nature nous respectons également notre corps, à
travers des vêtements
naturels qui
le laissent respirer et
protègent notre peau. 


Machii
aime les vêtements confortables, que l'on peut porter en toute
occasion. C'est pourquoi le chanvre est souvent mélangé à du coton
de jersey qui lui donne une certaine élasticité, et un retombé
fluide qui se laisse danser, bouger, respirer ! Machii aime que vous puissiez vous sentir confortable dans vos vêtements tout en restant féminine et élégante!




 Financement d'une surjetteuse/surfileuse


Le
jersey étant une fibre difficile à coudre avec une simple machine,
il est aujourd'hui plus que nécessaire d'acquérir une
surjeteuse/surfileuse professionnelle. Le jersey est un tissu qui se
détend très facilement, hors avec une surfileuse le tissu peut
être cousu sans se déformer. L'acquisition de cette surfileuse offre des possibilités qu'une machine normale ne peut pas offrir, et
ouvre la porte à une créativité qui donne libre cours à des
modèles toujours plus confortables  et élégants. Une surjetteuse permettra
également d'améliorer la qualité des  finitions, ainsi que la
durabilité et solidité des coutures, pour des créations que vous porterez encore plus longtemps! 

La surfileuse en question est une surfileuse de marque JUKI, MO-654DE.





Pourquoi contribuer à ce projet? 
Actuellement, n'ayant pas d'autres possibilités en Belgique, je paie 70 à 80 % de taxes, et il est encore aujourd'hui difficile pour moi d'obtenir les fonds nécessaires à l'achat d'une surfileuse professionnelle. C'est pourquoi je fais appel à vous, sachant que même la plus petite aide d'1, 2, 5, 10, 20 euros sera utile à la création d'une marque de vêtements fabriqués localement, qui respectent le corps et l'environnement, en proposant une alternative concrète à la pollution des sols, conscéquences directes de l'industrie du textile. Il me tient particulièrement à coeur de proposer des créations textiles sans produit chimiques qui n'entreront pas en interaction avec votre corps. Je m'applique à trouver des tissus naturels autant que possible en provenance d'une agriculture biologique et respectueuse de l'environnement ou la fibre a été cultivée. Il est également très important pour moi que mes créations puissent être portées de façon à se sentir bien dans son corps (et dans sa tête ! ) tout en apportant une touche d'élégance, de simplicité et de confort, d'où l'utilisation du chanvre et coton de jersey, qui permet cet élasticité et ce confort dans les mouvements. 


 Où me trouver et comment aider ? 


Actuellement,
je travaille dans mon propre petit atelier à Bruxelles.

Si
vous souhaitez connaître la démarche de Machii plus en profondeur,
je vous invite à découvrir mon site web : www.machii.be

Vous
avez également la possibilité de suivre les créations de Machii
via facebook : https://www.facebook.com/machiipachamama/

Egalement via ma boutique en ligne :
https://www.alittlemarket.com/boutique/machii-3049.htmlVous pouvez contribuer à ce projet en apportant une aide financière via indiegogo, ainsi qu'en partageant autour de vous. Le montant de votre don est libre, vous donnez absolument ce que vous voulez. Les montants fixes proposés vous offre une contrepartie en retour. Amicalement et avec toute ma gratitude, Machii

story:
Who are we?

We are the Association for the Preservation of the European Work of Dr. Serge Raynaud de la Ferrière, a non-profit organization comprised of volunteers. Since 1981 we have dedicated our efforts in continuing and disseminating the humanitarian work and avant-garde thought of De la Ferrière in the realms of art, science, philosophy and education. 


What is it about?

From June 11 – 22, 2016, we will be holding various activities in Nice (France) and Trieste (Italy) in honour of the 100-year anniversary of the birth of our founder, the French thinkerDr. Serge Raynaud de la Ferrière. Among the activities that we will be holding both in France and Italy is the art exhibit: East and West in the Works of Dr. Serge Raynaud de la Ferrière where a sample of De la Ferrière‘s art works will be presented. The sociological and anthropological value of the art works from this thinker who sought to unite the human experience in the evolution of history as well as the human experience of the different regions and traditions in the world, gives way to a sense of union and intercultural rapprochement, based on tolerance by means of understanding and the study of ancient and modern legacies and identities within the distinct cultures. He has defined pieces representing the East and the West, each with its own anthropological and socio-cultural particularities, promoting a self-cultivation, education and realization, penetrating into multiple concepts and symbols of both the past and present.

In addition, we will be organizing lectures, symposiums and workshops exploring De la Ferrière’s vision expressed not only in his paintings but also in his 100 literary works extending to topics in science, philosophy and education. We will as well be exploring other avant-garde humanitarian artists, scientists and thinkers.

We are currently facing the reality that in the areas in which we are holding these events, there are not many art and culture subsidies. We still haven’t reached the amount of money to cover our basic expenses and we need your help whether it be monetary or even with your time, in order to organize these events. 


Why and for what reason do we organize the event?

In harmony with the activities of the 100-year anniversary of our founder, we want to organize various activities promoting a greater and more profound understanding between different peoples, cultures, ideals, etc. in order to work towards a more tolerant and thus peaceful society. This is being done in various cities of the Americas but now we wish to take this to the European countries where our organization is located (in France and Italy) as a culmination of our activities.

Hence, activities such as the art exhibit East and West in the Works of Dr. Serge Raynaud de la Ferrière and the lecture The Union of Science and Art, a Basis for Tolerance will work towards these objectives through diverse mediums, whether it be within the realms of art, science, philosophy or didactics. In addition, the vanguard and humanitarian thought of other contemporary artists, scientists and thinkers will be disseminated.


The effect

The aforementioned activities will work in favor of a greater tolerance between different people, cultures, ideals, etc. through a greater understanding and active cooperation. The exhibits, lectures, symposiums, children workshops, etc. are both specific and broad in scope, and have precisely been organized in this way in order to meet the objectives of an interdisciplinary and intercultural tolerance, rapprochement and understanding.

It is by means of this synthesis and universal approach that the Association for the Preservation of the European Work of Dr. Serge Raynaud de la Ferrière improves the quality of our societies within the realms of science, art, philosophy and didactics. We seek to strengthen our cooperation and social projection with institutions that work in favour of social wellbeing such as UNESCO within the 18 countries where we are currently more active, primarily in Latin America.

Key volunteer members of our sister foundations will be present, foundations that as well work at both the grassroots and governmental level. These foundations include: The E.L.I.C. Foundation (Free Schools of Scientific Research for Children), The F.I.S.S. Foundation (International Federation of Scientific Societies), The INVESCIENCIAS Foundation (Research Institute of Scientific and Technological Applications) and the Magna Fraternitas Universalis Foundation. These foundations continually organize cultural, educational, artistic and scientific activities for the development and evolution of human wellbeing whether it be in children, youth or adults. Among these continual activities we find the World Conferences for Childhood Talent and the World Conferences of Scientific Youth which take place every two years in Latin America.


How can you support us?

With your donations, we would be able to finance the following:

  • Event Locations – rental of rooms and lecture halls where the events will take place

  • Materials – expenses of printing the materials and encasing the works

  • Transportation – transportation of art materials and personnel

  • Promotion – flyers, pamphlets, posters, social media and radio ads

  • Inviting local and international artists– explore the possibilities of subsidizing the travel expenses of certain artists from Europe and/or the Americas to participate in the event to present musical pieces, lectures, etc.


Other ways to support the event:

    • You can help us promote event through different social media

    • Coming to the event, everyone is welcome!


We thank you for your time, help and contributions! Please feel free to visit the websites indicated below or contact us via telephone at +(39) 3334236902 (Italy), +(33) 632509364 (France) or +(1) 4164775642 (Canada).


Best Regards,

The Organizing Committe

www.expo100aniversario.org

http://www.casacultura-it-magnanet.org/100-aniversario/

http://www.houseofculturecanada.org/

https://www.facebook.com/100ans.sr.dela.ferriere.nice/?fref=ts

story:
Supõe Se A Verdade Fosse Uma Mulher_ E Porque Não?

(Imagine If Truth Was A Woman_ And Why Not?)


Hello to All, my name is Euridice Kala and I am a visual artist based in Maputo, Mozambique. I am also a young and independent artist (no representation), which creates limitations on the resources I have available for the manifestation of my ideas aka projects. I see these not as deterrents to the process, but rather opportunities for new possibilities to arise.  
I have been invited/ accepted to participate in one of the most relevant and historical art events on the African Continent. And as I am proposing a new work, I have self funded part of the production, but still a few aspects to finalize the work.
This year the curator is making special reference to one of the biggest supporters of Art from the continent and its diaspora Sedar Senghor and I see it as a special moment to contribute work that communicates the various facets of Pan-African history- and I belive that the work I am displaying will make use of such references. 

I have been an practicing as an artist and really believe in the possibility of practice as process and in the continuation of decolonial thoughts and progressive work that  expand the contemporary identities. 
For the production of the work I will need 2000 USD, which will go for printing, purchasing material, assembling, and production of 3 video pieces that will feature in the installation. 

One of the biggest hurdles for a young, black, female artist from the continent is the lack supported from national and international institutions- and that diminishes the number of female artists who even believing in the value of their work stop (for various reasons) creating and sharing our valuable contributions with the world.

So even if you cannot financially contribute, SHARE IT widely!!! Be part of the next generation of artists who need their voices heard too!!  
Visit my blog (world) to see more of me.
http://euridicekala.blogspot.com/
And if you want to contact me directly just send me an email on: euridicekala@gmail.com

KHANIMAMBO
THANKS VERY VERY MUCH
OBRIGADA

story:
Short Summary

We are creating an art and spirituality education sanctuary at Wickerman Burn this year. In previous years there has not be a place to read, learn, experience the wide range of pagan and folk beliefs. We felt that it was important of others to understand the pagan/folk roots of similar festivals of old.  We want to make a space that would make this information easily accessible to people unfamiliar with these practices and beliefs. 

  • We are both artists and practicing pagans. We want the people attending Wickerman Burn to be more familiar with the pagan/folk roots of similar celebrations.
  • Teaching others about pagan and folk beliefs is very important to us, especially when engaging in a festival that is emblematic of pagan/folk traditions. 
  • While Zac and I will be bringing the learning materials and setting up this spiritual learning space, the participation of others is vital to the overall experience at the Temporary Temple. 
  • Learning about these pagan/folk beliefs combined with the creation of art will make for a very inclusive experience.

What We Need & What You Get

We have already received a grant for our project, but we will not be awarded the funds until the end of the event. With that in mind, please know that we don't need much, but we need a little to get started:

  • We need about $500 for learning materials such as books, art supplies, and handout materials for people to take with them, if they so desire. 
  • We hope for the overall experience at Temporary Temple to be moving and enriching no matter what level of experience you may have with pagan/folk ritual or art. We are going to create a space that allows one and all to be moved by the deeper meaning of the experience. Whether it be through the creation of art, the engagement in ritual, or through passive observance. 
  • Whatever funds we raise will go to the creation of the Temporary Temple at WickerBurn to create a peaceful, rich learning experience. 

The Impact

We hope that by creating this learning space we can bring new elements of artistic breath, as well as spiritual peace and knowledge to the Wickerman Burn community:

  • We want to help others learn more about mediation techniques, how folk rituals have a positive effect on everyday life, and generally demystify both pagan and folk beliefs. 
  • We want to make the environment and feel of this project as open as possible. This space is meant to be a place for an active exchange of ideas. 
  • We want to create a place to honor and understand Spirit through artistic expression.

Risks & Challenges

As previously stated, we do already have some funding, but unfortunately we can't utilize it immediately for our project. That is why we need your help.

  • Currently we cannot begin gathering information and materials at a stable rate since we do not have enough private money allocated for this project.
  • With a bit of seed money we would be able to start our project with less uncertainty and financial strain. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute monetarily, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Donate you time and help us gather materials, organize information, or suggest a way you would like to help out.
  • Please come visit us at Wicker Man Burn and join the conversation.
  • Share our IndieGoGo and tell your friends!

story:
About me:

I am a visual artist from Tokyo, Japan. I make objects and installations using clear materials such as glass, sugar, light, water and things that shift over time. I am practicing new ways to connect the worlds of studio glass and contemporary art through my own artwork and curatorial projects. I am launching this campaign to seek support for a new group exhibition titled"Emancipation: how to make a work of glass that isn't glass" which takes place in Corning, NY, USA. 
To view my full CV, please visit the link HERE.
    

    


Project Overview:

“Emancipation: how to make a work of glass that isn’t glass” is a curatorial project by Yuka Otani with an attempt to bring new perspectives of bridging the fields of studio glass and contemporary art. The project highlights artworks that derive inspirations from glass but executed without glass, posing questions to the term “glass art” which is often taken too granted today.

Rather than labeling themselves as material-specific art, the exemplified pieces suggest that the possibilities of glass as a creative medium may not only reside in the material itself but also in its metaphorical and conceptual planes. It will take place in Corning, NY coinciding with the upcoming Glass Art Society Conference on June 9-11, 2016.

The full exhibition statement is available from HERE.

Project Website: http://www.glass-emancipation.com


Background:   

The title of the exhibition is inspired by an essay titled “Czech Glass in a Context (2006) “written by Dr. Sylva Petrova in which she describes “emancipation from glass” as “one of the most typical features of the Czech glass education and practice” namely in the 80’s and 90’s. In that time, highly educated art students tried to subordinate glass to their art ideas. Thus, they were interested in glass “occasionally” when their projects required transparency, translucency or reflection. I found this term quite fascinating because I studied art in glass-specific curriculums and I felt similar when developing my own artwork. I learned many important things from the experience of working in glass and I did appreciate the depth of the techniques, however, I just did not want to limit my method to a single medium. For instance, I started making glass-like objects out of blown and cast hard candy, and it has become my ongoing series of work until today.  Thus “emancipation from glass” did happen to me, though there is still an apparent connection between the idea of “glass” and many of my non-glass works. And I also found this way of approach among my peer artists who studied in a glass program. Nowadays, “Emancipation from glass” may be observed in different places around the world where artists create works in the crossover fields of studio glass and contemporary art.  

It is important to make it clear that my definition of “Emancipation from glass” is not “anti-glass”. It does not bring negative connotations to the medium.  It brings unique perspectives to look at glass, which is different from the conventional perspectives of “glass art”. Here I’d like to quote Dr. Petrova’s words again from our email conversations. “….they (artists who emancipated glass) must be accepted in a rank of glass because they are working with glass in spite in a different way ( in a new role) than others….” “Czech glass scene is quite colorful today. Me as an art historian, however, is still fascinated by the pieces bordering fine art which are very inspiring, very experimental and give the world glass movement very special value.” 

Note:  “Emancipation from glass” is a departure point for this project, but the concept and selection of the artists in the exhibition are made through my personal interpretation of the term. 

Participating Artists:

The exhibition includes sculpture, video, and installations by following artists who have very intelligent and experimental approaches to glass.

Anne Petters(Germany/UK)  http://www.annepetters.com/
W. Benjamin Bray(USA) http://www.benbray.com/
David King(USA) http://davidjohnking.com/
Helen Lee(USA) http://pink-noise.org/
Justin Ginsberg(USA) http://justinginsberg.net/
Shari Mendelson(USA) http://www.sharimendelson.com/
J. Susie Hwang(USA) http://www.jsusiehwang.com/
Yuka Otani(Japan) http://www.yukaotani.com/

The Exhibition:

The exhibition will run from June 9-11, 2016 in Corning, NY coinciding with the upcoming Glass Art Society Conference.  The exhibition venue will be a pop-up gallery utilizing a storefront on Market Street in Downtown Corning. The exact location and further information will be announced on http://glass-emancipation.com/  as soon as the venue is finalized… so please stay tuned! 

Corning, also known as “Crystal City” is a small town but it has a rich history in glass because of the world’s leading glass company, Corning Inc. and the Corning Museum of Glass.

I had previously organized DIY pop-up exhibitions in downtown Corning twice and this will be the third time. In 2009, I co-curated my first experimental glass exhibition titled “how is this glass?” with a peer artist Anjali Srinivasan. In 2015, I spent 5 weeks in Corning as an artist in residence at the Corning Museum of Glass, and I organized a two-person exhibition"COExist" with a fellow resident artist, Justin Ginsberg to present the outcomes of the residency program. Both the projects (especially “how is this glass?”, showing works by approx. 30 artists) were labor-intensive but quite rewarding. I have established good connections with the local community, and I am very much looking forward to presenting another project there again. 

        

Photo above: The town of Corning, NY
Photo below left: Opening reception of "how is this glass?" exhibition, 2009
Photo below right: Opening reception of "COExist" exhibition, 2015 (photo by Lee Speary)

What I Need Money for:

I am working with the local organizations in Corning to make this project happen. The ARTS Council of the Southern Finger Lakes and Corning’s Gaffer District are generously offering an exhibition venue and liability insurance coverage. Still, I will be responsible for the remaining expenses that include promotional costs, catalog publication, shipping fee(partial), my traveling and lodging expenses, and miscellaneous costs related to the installation of the artworks.  The details go as follows: 

Catalog printing cost: $650
Miscellaneous installation costs: $200
Partial shipping fee: $500
Promotional costs(signs, posters, partial production cost of the perks): $300
Lodging+food (7 nights in Corning, NY) $350
Roundtrip airfare (between Tokyo, Japan and Corning, NY) $1500


The total cost estimate is $3500. If the campaign achieves beyond the goal, any additional contributions go towards upgrading catalog design, work shipping fee and my personal travel expenses. If the campaign does not reach the goal, the exhibition will still happen. All the money raised will be invested to the exhibition cost and I will be paying the rest out of my pocket. 


What You Get:

In return to your generous support, I’m offering a variety of perks.
For further details, please see the "Perks" section.

$5: Your name on the website
Yes! a small contribution does matter. Your name will be credited on the project website.

$15: A personalized thank you email
I will send you a personalized thank you message, PLUS your name will be credited on the project website.

$25: A digital PDF catalog
I will send you a PDF digital catalog of the exhibition, PLUS your name will be credited on the project website.

$50: A printed catalog
I will send you a signed hard copy of the exhibition catalog, PLUS your name will be credited on the project website.

$75: Make your own "Emancipation"latte! (new)

laser cut acrylic latte templates , a set of two  H10cm xW10cm(4”x4”)

“Emancipation Latte” is a drinkable work of art that I will be making in collaboration with Soul Full Cup Coffeehouse. The latte will be available at the exhibition venue during June 9th-11th, but I’d also like to offer the template so that you can make your own at home!  You will also receive a signed hard copy of the exhibition catalog, PLUS your name will be credited on the project website.


$125: Sugar silkscreen prints by Yuka Otani (new)

“Rediscovering Nostalgia: Sugarcane Farmers”  by Yuka Otani (2015)
silkscreen print on paper using sugar ink 
limited editions signed&unframed, a set of two
W27cm xH39cm(10 3/4” x 15 1/2”)

“Rediscovering Nostalgia” is a series of silkscreen prints produced during the residency at a 100-year-old former sugar refinery factory building at Kio-A-Thau Sugar Refinery Artist Village in Kaohsiung, Taiwan. I photographed relaxed, smiley faces of local sugarcane farmers(they are a couple)and transferred the imagery into silkscreen prints using raw sugar ink. You will also receive a signed hard copy of the exhibition catalog, PLUS your name will be credited on the project website.


$175: “Bubble” photograph by Yuka Otani (new) 

“Bubble Floating over Pilchuck Glass School” (2014)
C-print on paper, signed&framed(glass top), limited editions
W25cm xH25cm x D5cm(10” x10” x 1 3/4”)

The work was produced during the emerging artist residency at Pilchuck Glass School in Washington State, USA. The thin and iridescent membrane of the photographed soap bubble reflects Pilchuck’s campus and surrounding nature. 5 different variations are available and you can choose one from the series#01,#03,#04,#06 and #08. You will also receive a signed hard copy of the exhibition catalog, PLUS your name will be credited on the project website.

<#01>


<#03>


<#04>



<#06>


<#08>


$250: “Vitreous” photograph by Yuka Otani (new) 

“Vitreous” (2014)
C-print on paper, signed&framed(aluminium frame/glass top), limited editionsW40cm x H50cm xD1.5cm (16” x20”x5/8”)

“Vitreous” was first presented at Oriental Design Gallery in Hiroshima, Japan in 2014. The photograph captures “vitreous” moments of candy glass objects created by the artist. 3 different versions are available and you can choose one from the series #A, #B, and#C. You will also receive a signed hard copy of the exhibition catalog, PLUS your name will be credited on the project website.

<#A>

     

<#B>  

    

<#C>

     


$750: A lecture
I’d like to offer you a lecture in which I will talk about the ongoing research in this project and my own art practice in person or via Skype. You will also receive a signed hard copy of the exhibition catalog (shipping included), PLUS your name, logo and/or website address will be credited in the exhibition catalog and project website as an official sponsor. (Please note: Traveling expenses related to the lecture needed to be paid separately.)

The Impact

The exhibition, this time, will be targeted to a very specific type of audience, mainly the Glass Art Society Conference attendees. However, it has potentials traveling to bigger cities in the U.S. and possibly abroad so that it’ll be exposed to the larger and diverse group of audiences in the arts field and beyond.  This is a still a beginning of my ongoing research project, but that is why it means a lot to present this exhibition in the best manner so that it can generate a path for progress. 

Risks & Challenges

The idea of “an exhibition about glass without glass” is an unusual theme, thus, it has not been presented in a context of studio glass because it’s not “glass art”.  I am very thankful to all the participating artists who have empathy for the project and are willing to contribute works to it. To see the outcome, the exhibition simply needs to happen.

Curating an exhibition in the U.S. from a remote place(Japan) is also a big challenge. However, I am committed to the exhibition, so any contributions will be used and will help offset  expenses I will be paying out of my pocket.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Of course, I appreciate not only financial contributions but all other kinds of support! Please spread the words about this project by sharing the links to this page and/or the project website. http://glass-emancipation.com/  

And if any of you will be visiting Corning area during the second weekend of June, please come see the exhibition and say hi to me! !

About me:
I am a visual artist from Tokyo, Japan. I make objects and installations using clear materials such as glass, sugar, light, water and things that shift over time. I am practicing new ways to connect the worlds of studio glass and contemporary art through my own artwork and curatorial projects. I am launching this campaign to seek support for a new group exhibition titled"Emancipation: how to make a work of glass that isn't glass" which takes place in Corning, NY, USA. To view my full CV, please visit the link HERE.

        






Project Overview:

“Emancipation: how to make a work of glass that isn’t glass” is a curatorial project by Yuka Otani with an attempt to bring new perspectives of bridging the fields of studio glass and contemporary art. The project highlights artworks that derive inspirations from glass but executed without glass, posing questions to the term “glass art” which is often taken too granted today.
Rather than labeling themselves as material-specific art, the exemplified pieces suggest that the possibilities of glass as a creative medium may not only reside in the material itself but also in its metaphorical and conceptual planes. It will take place in Corning, NY coinciding with the upcoming Glass Art Society Conference on June 9-11, 2016.
The full exhibition statement is available from HERE.


Project Website: http://www.glass-emancipation.com
Background:   
The title of the exhibition is inspired by an essay titled “Czech Glass in a Context (2006) “written by Dr. Sylva Petrova in which she describes “emancipation from glass” as “one of the most typical features of the Czech glass education and practice” namely in the 80’s and 90’s. In that time, highly educated art students tried to subordinate glass to their art ideas. Thus, they were interested in glass “occasionally” when their projects required transparency, translucency or reflection. I found this term quite fascinating because I studied art in glass-specific curriculums and I felt similar when developing my own artwork. I learned many important things from the experience of working in glass and I did appreciate the depth of the techniques, however, I just did not want to limit my method to a single medium. And I also found this way of approach among my peer artists who studied in a glass program. Me as an art historian, however, is still fascinated by the pieces bordering fine art which are very inspiring, very experimental and give the world glass movement very special value.” 
Note:  “Emancipation from glass” is a departure point for this project, but the concept and selection of the artists in the exhibition are made through my personal interpretation of the term.

The exhibition includes sculpture, video, and installations by following artists who have very intelligent and experimental approaches to glass.

Benjamin Bray(USA) http://www.benbray.com/David King(USA) http://davidjohnking.com/Helen Lee(USA) http://pink-noise.org/Justin Ginsberg(USA) http://justinginsberg.net/Shari Mendelson(USA) http://www.sharimendelson.com/J. Susie Hwang(USA) http://www.jsusiehwang.com/Yuka Otani(Japan) http://www.yukaotani.com/

The exhibition will run from June 9-11, 2016 in Corning, NY coinciding with the upcoming Glass Art Society Conference.  The exhibition venue will be a pop-up gallery utilizing a storefront on Market Street in Downtown Corning. The exact location and further information will be announced on http://glass-emancipation.com/  as soon as the venue is finalized… so please stay tuned!

Both the projects (especially “how is this glass?”, showing works by approx. 30 artists) were labor-intensive but quite rewarding. I have established good connections with the local community, and I am very much looking forward to presenting another project there again.

story:
PARKT!

PARKT is an innovative event that promotes community progress with a combination of regenerating artistic initiatives that enrich its participants and the community with alternative practices.

@ THE PAVILION,

KING ST

GREAT YARMOUTH 

28TH AUGUST 2016

  • Graffiti Competition 
  • Dance Battle
  • Live Music
  • Workshops

What We Need 


  • Materials - £736
  • Soundsystem - £150
  • Venue Permits - £260
  • Workshops - £120
  • Event Production - £234
  • Total: £1500 
Reprezent Project aims
    1. Provide Cultural events in the heart of the local community by engaging with arts, sports, education and professional guidance and support.
    2. Propose public project that inspire, nurture and provide a solution to local social issues.
    3. Explore the cultural diversity represented in the area by promoting local and international traditions in order to encourage recognition and acceptance of different values.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that it's not always possible for people to donate, but there are tons of other ways! 

Please spread the word about this page and follow us on Youtube Channel, Facebook & Twitter.

Thank you for keeping the art alive... 

"INVEST IN US & WE WILL INVEST IN YOU"!

story:
Floatra is a floating three-sided pyramid with an LED lighting system and phosphorescent detailing that glows in the dark for hours. It is large enough to be a floating structure swimmers can climb and lounge on. Debuting at Symbiosis in September, Floatra is a collaboration between ̄knautwerk (Daniel Anderson), Aux Industries (Caroline Margaux), and the non-profit artist driven gallery Merchants of Reality.

Symbiosis has generously promised a partial budget for Floatra. Our minimum budget covers structural materials, the floatation devices, and the lighting system, which will be waterproof.

We need your help to make Floatra a reality this September. Every little bit helps—and we have a great list of perks you could get in thanks for your contribution!

Our Team

Daniel Anderson (̄knautwerk) - Design & Engineering

Daniel Anderson is a creative technologist and visual artist. Anderson has been working with tetrahedrons and three-sided pyramids for years, building them into all scales and styles of projection-mapped installations.

Caroline Margaux (Aux Industries) - Construction & Electrical

Caroline Margaux is a lighting engineer and luminosity expert, particularly with LEDs and infinity mirror effects. With many commercial and non-commercial installations completed, Margaux brings her lighting expertise and construction experience to the Floatra project.

Our Extended Team: Merchants of Reality, The P.E.A.C.E. Museum, and a cast and crew of dedicated volunteers ranging from engineers, to film-makers, musicians, electricians, and even U.S. Navy.

The Vision

Floatra will be 18.5' long on each side and 9' tall. Its three walls will sit on an triangular platform, inside which sits fifteen 30 gallon sealed barrels, creating buoyancy for over 20 passengers.​

​Floatra's battery-powered waterproof lighting system will consist of hundreds of addressable LEDs concentrated at its top. Europium resin-cast "barnacles" that glow in the dark will be placed on its bottom edges. Europium powder has natural phosphorescence that lasts brightly for hours, and is non-toxic and non-radioactive.

Floatra will be a stationary, LED and naturally phosphorescent watercraft. Climbing ropes along the platform and underwater ladders will assist passengers aboard.

The Perks!

We've got an awesome array of rewards and goodies for our backers. Get a vinyl sticker of Floatra, a europium-doped resin cast tetrahedron (glows blue for hours), infinity mirror tetrahedrons, or a private musical session by The Genie himself at his specially lit studio at the Honey Hive Gallery.​

Our Goals

Our minimum budget for Floatra is $2,000. Symbiosis has generously promised half of that. We need $3,000 so we can build our master plan that includes 800 LEDs, glow-in-the-dark features, inner decor, and more.

Best of all, Floatra can scale based on the recieved budget. We can always add more barrels to the foundation and build her bigger!

story:
Chanukah falls exactly from Christmas to New Year's this year! We light the first candle of the menorah on Christmas Eve!! I am inspired to create art that is a nod to both traditions. My mind's eye is filled with twinkling lights and candles, song, good food, comfort and joy...

Please, celebrate with me!

Original Artwork by Janis Loewengart Yerington can be viewed at- www.BolinasFolkArt.com and www.MaxsBible.com

More pictures of cards at www.HappyChrismukah.com

story: Hello, I'm Caroline Stephenson.  Mom, educator, DGA assistant director, book lover, and Northeastern NC native.  This campaign is to help raise startup funds to open an independent bookstore in rural, economically challenged Northeastern NC.  This campaign is important to me because knowledge is power.  Currently, area  residents have very little access to books.  There's Walmart, several Dollar Stores, thrift stores, and religious book stores.  Yes, books are available at these retailers, but they don't offer a wide variety of books nor personalized one-on-one service.  Cultivator is more than just a bookstore.  It's a gathering place for the community to forge unity and progress.  Contributors to this campaign will help us achieve this from the ground up.  Our $7500 goal breaks down to $6000 in rent for a year and $1500 toward other startup costs (connecting wifi, utility deposits, building bookshelves, paint, cleaning supplies).   We wanted to set a realistic goal for starting an independent bookstore in a small, rural town that has never had one before.  If we don't meet our entire goal, then we will still utilize the funds to cover the rent and expenses for as far as the money will go.  Rural America in the 21st Century faces many challenges:  population decline, lack of employment and educational opportunities, transportation and communication issues.  Approximately 35% of children here live in poverty.  Only 14% of our population have a Bachelor's degree or higher.  By contributing to this project, you can help mitigate some of the damage done in the past 20 years caused by big box stores and jobs moving overseas.  Cultivator adds to the local economy, instead of taking away.   It will be a place where local artist will have their work on display and for sale.  Community members  will be able to place their books on consignment.  Artists will hold art workshops and art talks.  Authors will hold book signings and discussions.  Book clubs will gather.  There is a definite risk involved starting a new business in a rural, high-poverty area, but we feel the benefits outweigh the obstacles.  The site for Cultivator has many things going for it.  It's on Main Street in Murfreesboro next to the public library.  Murfreesboro is a college town, home to Chowan University.  Chowan University is home to nearly 1500 students.  Will we meet challenges along the way?  Most definitely.  But our plan is to start small and local, featuring a variety of new and used books, textbooks, and art by local authors and artists, and grow from there.  Thank you for your time and consideration.  Every dollar counts!  Please share!  If you have questions, please do not hesitate to call me at 252-395-2327. Or email at cultivatornc@gmail.com.

story:
THANK YOU!!!

THANK YOU to everyone that donated to our Indiegogo campaign, shared it with a friend, or sent your love our way. We couldn't build this amazing, giant art without you and are so incredibly grateful for all your love & support! ❤️ 

Follow our progress to the playa )'( through our Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/brlighthouse/ and on our Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/brlighthouseservice/

SCHWAG 

Interested in getting some more Lighthouse schwag? Donate to our GoFundMe (http://bit.ly/1S3jmLY) and email us (donations@brlighthouse.org) with your selection and mailing address. We'll hook you up! Check out photos of the schwag here: http://bit.ly/1XuBLsX - scroll to the bottom of the page.

1) Lighthouse Patch - Patch it up! These gorgeous circular black and gold patches feature the Lighthouse's logo in full glory. Handcrafted by Lighthouse crew member Jason Privett. - $20 USD + Shipping ($5 USA, $7 worldwide) 

2) BRLS Logo T-Shirt - Black T-shirt with the BRLS logo screen printed on the front. Available in sizes M-XL. - $35 USD + Shipping ($6 USA, $15 worldwide)

3) BRLS Logo Female Tank Top - Black tank top with the BRLS logo screen printed on the front, women's cut. Available in sizes S-XL. - $35 USD + Shipping ($6 USA, $15 worldwide) 

4) BRLS Logo Zip Hoodie - Black zip hoodie with the BRLS logo. Available in sizes S-XL. - $65 USD + Shipping ($6 USA, $15 worldwide)

5) Limited Edition Print - Own 1 of 10 Prints of Max Poynton's original drawings of the main Lighthouse. Each one will be signed and framed in wood that we will remove from the Lighthouses before the burn. > only 3 left < - $275 USD + Shipping ($15 USA, $30 worldwide) 

6) Fly Above the Playa! - A Bird's Eye View of Burning Man could be YOURS. Fly above the playa in an aerobatic VANS RV4 aircraft. This 2 seat aircraft will fly above the playa allowing you a bird's eye view of the festivities and will then exit the Burning Man Airspace and conduct some aerobatics (if you feel up to it). - $1500 USD 

7) Own a Lighthouse - We will build you an 8ft (or smaller if you like) Lighthouse that you can place in your yard, give to your kids, or maybe even give one to your cats for the most luxurious playhouse ever! The Lighthouse will be based on the design of the actual Lighthouses that will be at Burning Man this year; however, we are happy to customize them to some degree if you wish. Delivery to the San Francisco Bay Area only. If you really want one and live further away, contact info@brlighthouse.org - $3250 USD

Let's Fire Up the Black Rock Lighthouse Service!

From the team that brought you the Bottlecap Gazebo, The Temple at Burning Man 2013 - The Temple of Whollyness, last year's Totem of Confessions, and multiple Flux Foundation projects - we now present... The Black Rock Lighthouse Service!!

We’re building a crystal-like cluster of lighthouses, including our main one that’s 60 ft. high and shoots flames (!!!), and we need your help. If all goes according to plan, these lighthouses will be the ultimate destination at Burning Man 2016. To do that, the bells and whistles need to come out! Lighthouses need light, yes. We're taking it a step further. We think they need FIRE.

Your contribution will enable us to enable these lighthouses to do their proper job. When you're lost, tired, or just can't seem to find your way on the playa, look for the fiery flames shooting from the peaks of our lighthouses, and your path will be lit.
A huge THANK YOU to everyone that contributed to our first campaign (https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-black-rock-lighthouse-service)  - please SHARE this new campaign and help us bring the FIRE! 

 [AfrikaBurn 2016. Photo by Claudia Kaufmann]

Yes, we know, this is a very ambitious project. We've been talking and dreaming about it for years, and now it's finally happening! Your donation of $5 or $500 helps us get one shingle closer to the sky! And every little bit of moral support helps too - invite your friends to like our Facebook page, talk us up, and spread the light!

The lighthouses are being built at American Steel Studios in West Oakland by an all-volunteer team of experienced artists, carpenters, designers, and veteran Burning Man attendees. This project has been in the planning stages for nearly five years. There have been multiple rounds of technical feedback into the design process, and we have established contingency plans around funding and key decision points. 


What We Need & What You Get

The Flame Edition: what we're asking you to help us buy

  • $10,000 worth of construction materials (steel, welding, etc.) and propane for all the flame effects
  • $2,000 worth of wood support in screws, bolts, nuts, and fixings

This just gets us the FIRE BASICS and we have far more ambitious plans if we can raise more money. If you want to see something truly amazing this year, please help us out. If we don't reach our goal, we will have fire on the top 3 lighthouses instead of all of them. 

Like our Facebook page to stay up-to-date on all the latest happenings: https://www.facebook.com/brlighthouse

And subscribe to our events, so you don't miss our next party! Keep a look out for our next ones in Oakland and Los Angeles: https://www.facebook.com/brlighthouse/events

Amazing Perks

The Health Pack

Some of the Other Perks

Lighthouse Patches

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to make a tax deductible donation, please contact info@brlighthouse.org and we can issue a tax receipt. If you can't donate but have some amazing old wood or antique nautical equipment, we are located at American Steel in Oakland, CA and would love to hear from you!

Thank You! from Jonny, Max, and the Lighthouse Crew )'(

story:
Sobre Amusic


Amusic Sociedad Cooperativa Integral es la institución que produce y fomenta el Festivalillo. 
Amusic SCI es una sociedad sin ánimo de lucro que promueve la integración laboral y profesional, la plena  inserción socioeconómica, la autorealización, la defensa de personas con dificultad de integración, la satisfacción de necesidades sociales no atendidas, o atendidas insuficientemente por el mercado y las instituciones públicas.
Amusic SCI desarrolla las actividades necesaria para fomentar el autoempleo de sus socios y crea y ofrece empleo en ámbito cultural y educativo.
FESTIVALILLO
La primera edición del Festivalillo (septiembre 2015) fue planteada como edición piloto. Se hizo hincapié en la multiculturalidad de la escena musical isleña, en el encuentro con músicos provenientes de capitales europeas, el encuentro con artistas visuales y en la danza, que durante el evento buscaba un hueco para crecer y hacerse un espacio. 
En la segunda edición (del 19  al 25 septiembre de 2016) se desarrolla un programa formativo en Danza Contemporánea, para jóvenes y adultos de todos los niveles: inicial, intermedio, avanzado, profesional y público en general. Durante la semana del Festivallillo 2016 se ofrecen clases y talleres (workshops) de técnicas contemporáneas, Graham, mixta, flamenco, danza urbana y ballet  así como un concurso de videoarte. La meta es captar público para la danza fomentando las artes complementarias como la música y el videoarte.
La sección VideoArte presenta una selección de obras. El público otorga un premio a través de la votación popular. También está el Visual jam, que es un espacio para la creación colectiva, extemporánea, donde lo visual se pone a disposición de la danza y la música.
******************************
"LA CREATIVIDAD ES UNA CUESTIÓN COLECTIVA"
Colaborando con el Festivalillo :
  • estás apoyando la realización de un evento cultural multidisciplinario, joven, comprometido, abierto y libre;
  • estás fomentando el estudio, la práctica de la danza, de la música y del videoarte, su fusión e investigación⍮
  • estás impulsando el trabajo en el ámbito cultural⍮
  • estás promoviendo el desarrollo de un turismo cultural y responsable⍮
  • estás contribuyendo al cuidado del medio ambiente⍮
Con tu colaboración el Festival logrará:
  • Consolidar un evento singular enfocado en la danza, el videarte y sus artes complementarias.
  • Aportar una alternativa a la oferta cultural de Fuerteventura y las islas canarias.
  • Impulsar acciones para facilitar la integración, la inserción, la autorealización, a través del arte.
     Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes
Necesitamos recaudar 4000 euros para: 
  • Ofrecer premios incentivos al estudio y bolsas de estudio a artistas destacados.
  • Contratar personal técnico y de producción y logística durante la semana del festival.
  • Contratar artistas invitados y locales: músicos y realizadores audiovisuales.

    En el caso de que no logremos la meta total prevista, la suma de lo recaudado se repartirá equitativamente.
LA CREATIVIDAD ES CUESTIÓN COLECTIVA.  ¡CREA!
  • Fuerteventura, Canarias, España, Europa, el mundo en general necesita de Festivales que fomenten el intercambio, que ofrezcan estímulos para la creación y que brinden otro punto de vista en favor de una sociedad critica y sana capaz de expresar, y de expresarse.  
  • La primera edición del Festivalillo generó mucha satisfacción en el público asistente.  La segunda edición ofrecerá una semana entera de formación, performances, fusiones, arte, música y danza.
Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar
También puedes ayudar al Festivalillo de la siguiente forma:
     
  • Difundiendo esta campaña.
  • Haciéndote Voluntario: si tienes tiempo disponible y quieres ponerte a disposición para colaborar en el logro de nuestras metas escribe a amusic.productora@gmail.com indicando en el asunto: Voluntario Festivalillo 2016. 
CONTAMOS CON TU AYUDA.
¡Muchísimas Gracias!

Contratar artistas invitados y locales: músicos y realizadores audiovisuales.En el caso de que no logremos la meta total prevista, la suma de lo recaudado se repartirá equitativamente.

LA CREATIVIDAD ES CUESTIÓN COLECTIVA.  ¡CREA!

Fuerteventura, Canarias, España, Europa, el mundo en general necesita de Festivales que fomenten el intercambio, que ofrezcan estímulos para la creación y que brinden otro punto de vista en favor de una sociedad critica y sana capaz de expresar, y de expresarse.  

La primera edición del Festivalillo generó mucha satisfacción en el público asistente.  La segunda edición ofrecerá una semana entera de formación, performances, fusiones, arte, música y danza.


Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

También puedes ayudar al Festivalillo de la siguiente forma: Difundiendo esta campaña.
Haciéndote Voluntario: si tienes tiempo disponible y quieres ponerte a disposición para colaborar en el logro de nuestras metas escribe a amusic.productora@gmail.com indicando en el asunto: Voluntario Festivalillo 2016. 

CONTAMOS CON TU AYUDA.¡Muchísimas Gracias!

story:
Je passe par le crownd founding afin de financer mon avenir : mon atelier de verrier.

L'argent sollicité sera utilisé pour les points suivants :

  • Acheter les outils nécessaires et vitaux au métier.
  • Créer un stock de verres et de plombs.
  • Aménager mon atelier (acheter une table, des tréteaux et du contreplaqué).

Je ne sollicite ce financement pour rien de plus ou de moins que les besoins essentiels et vitaux au démarrage de mon entreprise.

La difficulté majeure est la clientèle. 

Pour cela, fort de mes 6 ans de métier, j'ai un carnet de contact qui me permettra de réaliser mes premiers chantiers. 

Je compte faire parler de moi grâce à un blog et des publications sur les réseaux sociaux.

Ci joint, les dépenses en fournitures, je vais essayer de mettre les dépenses en matière premieres prochainement !
