story:
#5KRiels: For the Life of Cambodian Shadow Puppet?

5000 Riels (1.25 dollars) for the life of Cambodian Shadow Puppet, basically know as Sbek Thom in Cambodian language, is projected with the purposes of preserving, enhancing the quality and most importantly inspiring the younger generation about the Sbek Thom Theater.

5000 Riels for Sbek Thom was born right after we had heard the saddest news that Mr. Mann Kosal, known as master of L’khon Sbek and the founder of Sovannaphum Arts Association planned to change his career from the theater director to the Tuk-Tuk driver and settled his life in one province in Cambodia. Our hearts dropped knowing this announcement from one of our team as we highly respect his talents, commitments and sacrifices through years to come to this point, and most importantly, as Cambodians, we could not let this world art heritage – Puppet Shadow Theater die and leave nothing for the next generation.

The theater is performed every Friday and Saturday at the association; the number of both local and international audiences decrease from one week to another because of the lack of human resource in operating, managing and marketing both performances and the association. With no supports from neither government, public nor any NGOs, Master Kosal have been struggling years and years in balancing the income and expenses until these recent days that he was totally hopeless in carry on his dream.

The only inspiration holding on him to go through all obstacles over years is to see the next generation knows and loves Sbek Thom Theater and to make sure that it is well preserved. Fight alone, he will not be able to accomplish, but fight together will do.

Without Sovannaphum theatre, there will be no Sbek Thom. As Sbek Thom now is in crisis, only people like you will help us to achieve this goal by sustain this performance art into life.


What is the problem?

Click here: News on Phnom Penh Post Newspaper: Even master craftsmen need to pay the rent

Founded in 1994 in Phnom Penh, Sovanna Phum Art Association was established by Master Mann Kosal to revive Sbek Thom shadow puppetry, an art form lost during the Khmer Rouge regime. Since then, the association has stayed true to his vision by being a platform for young Cambodians to reinstate their cultural heritages and express themselves through art.

Over the past 22 years since he first picked up the skills of performance and puppet making from Masters Pech Tom Krovil, Cheng Phon and Prin Sakhorn, Master Kosal has devoted himself to the improvement of Khmer shadow puppetry. Beyond the revival of Sbek Thom, in itself an intangible heritage, Master Kosal is also central to the advancement of puppetry and ways of keeping Sbek Thom relevant to a modernising Cambodia. Despite the humble beginnings of Sovanna Phum, when Master Kosal began telling stories with only four large shadow puppets, he never stopped making more and better puppets to share even more sophisticated legends and empowering tales. Recently inspired by Kelantan puppetry, he seeks to create large colored shadows to tell the story of the beginnings of Hanuman, an episode less common due to its lack of action and movements.

Click here: 360degree picture of Sovannaphum theatre and stage

The impact of Sovanna Phum has helped sustain and develop recognition of the once lost art form to this day. For its first ten years, Sbek Thom and Master Kosal’s intriguing performances drew more than 100 artists to the association with approximately 100 audiences a day. Till today, Master Kosal also grooms street children or relatives of his artists with food, shelter, and even money for education so those interested in the arts may pick up more knowledge and practice with the association. Master Kosal also conscientiously wrote stories and directed performances to educate the wider public on knowledge of such issues as environmental cleanliness and safe sex. Thus both artists and the community benefitted from Master Kosal and the Sovanna Phum Art Association through their art and community engagement.

Unfortunately since the mid-2000’s, the economy and demand for space in Phnom Penh changed dramatically. Master Kosal’s founding partner and manager left the association for personal reasons, and the association had to change its venue to reduce rental costs. Unfortunately their move has not boded well for its outreach, and without opportunities for arts management training and employment, the association’s artists have since dwindled to 10, with insufficient income for Master Kosal himself and the association’s volunteer managers and their increasing health costs. With artists now only receiving 5 USD per performance in spite of rising costs, artist retention and hours for rehearsals have been on the decline. This has gone to the extent that the Phnom Penh Post interviewed and reported on 10th June 2016 of Master Kosal’s plan for a career change.

Click Here: 360 degree picture of Sovannaphum performance and behind the white screen

This situation is symptomatic of a recovering country now mined for its land and resources whose people have yet and cannot catch up to the new economy. Rental is rising at approximately 7-15% a year, even though no free or accessible opportunities for skill development or education exists. Government officials and NGOs themselves are steered by the incoming investments of East Asia with insufficient support for craftsmen and other industries such as Mann Kosal. Artists clamor for funding and job opportunities with insufficient time and foresight to foster development among other artists. Few craftsmen and artists can afford to speak English and French. Not enough information therefore reaches the international aid organisations for an effective countrywide support of the Khmer arts.


Master Kosal is no stranger to international ideas and exchange, and could have been a world-renowned artist if not for the impacts of the Cold War, the Khmer Rouge and the lack of effective humanitarian aid in South East Asia. To date, he has travelled to a total of 45 countries presenting his innovate skills and high quality work. Concomitantly, Master Kosal has brought Sbek Thom in its most original form to these many countries, even introducing it to such esteemed persons as Princess Diana, which now sits alongside other intangible practices classified as an UNESCO World Heritage. Given his unyielding determination and enduring love for the art, he is one of the only Sbek Thom masters left in Cambodia today. Uniquely, Kosal also believes in imparting all of his knowledge to his disciples, unlike those before him. Given the resources, he would seek all manner of research, development and education of Khmer stories, art and performance.


What We Hope

Our goal is to raise between 12,000 to 30,000 USD to keep the association running for 6 more months. This is to meet its basic needs, estimated at 5,000 USD per month, and develop Sovanna Phum’s arts management, artist recruitment and marketing for its long term sustainability.

The group hopes to revive Sovanna Phum’s educational shows and provide a development plan for the association’s artists, especially Master Kosal, to prevent the effacement of this rich part of Khmer culture.



The Impact

We are creating a movement in order to save Large Shadow Puppetry. Large Shadow Puppetry has been included as a national heritage in the 25th November 2005. Despite various kinds of promoting , the Large Shadow Puppetry gradually be forgotten and the lack of care of this defamation legacy that makes the market of Large Shadow Puppetry lost almost no known today.

That is why we created this project to preserve and develop Large Shadow Puppetry stability to share to the younger generation to learn about their national culture and we also want to show to the international guests to recognize this marvelous Khmer art as well.

These outreach programmes wold also help develop future audiences and Cambodian society at large, especially its youths, so they mat have and be part of an intangible world heritage, for greater pride and understanding of what it means to be Khmer.


The Team

This initiation came from a group of young Cambodian youths, Plerng Kob who passionately interest in arts, especially this form of theater is trying our best with the help of UNIMA Singapore to preserve this cultural art, because it is our national symbol to the world.

1.  Plerng Kob

Plerng kob is a non-profit organization by students on the mission to bring life back to the old art forms of Cambodia by creating cultural art events, such as the annual folk-festival called “Bonn Phum”, literally means “Village festival” in pagodas in Cambodia, as a means of saving the arts and cultural events, in particular “Sbek Thom” (Shadow puppetry) to Cambodian young generation and Cambodian as a whole.

This year Plerng Kob is making efforts to preserve and develop Sbek Thom, which was listed as the intangible cultural heritage of humanity by the UNESCO. As the young generation who has a great passion of art, we cannot stand and see our art disappear without having a proper solutions. That is why we are here to help sustain and give back the performance art that is a symbol of national heritage to the next generation.




2.  UNIMA-Singapore

Singapore's national centre for the international puppetry association, UNIMA-Singapore is focused on developing the puppet arts of Singapore and its region of Southeast Asia.


Risks & Challenges

These are the facts that we're focused on improving and repair the structure of the association by having additional staffs to work on permanent and specific sections to make it easier to solve problems that are encountered as described above. Moreover, increasing the ability to perform is needed to attract the attention of viewers but we need funding assistance to them for regular rehearsals. The tools and performance equipment also needs further improvement. Especially, the promotion of Large Shadow Puppetry main job is to provide specific information about the schedule of the performances to the audience.

With such a problem has occurred, coupled with a large number of issues, such as:

1: There is no proper management structure in the association (no employees working full time for the association because of the lost income and couldn't afford to provide decent wages for employees and long-lasting).

2: There is no manager in media and advertisement and marketing, which is not ideal that cause reduction to national and international audiences to even fewer and fewer.

3: Lack of financial strength to maintain and stabilize the core of association.

4: Lack of new art forms (the majority of artists in the association couldn't stay for long because they can not survive without income so artists who come to learn or want to continue performing become less and less and can't stay longer, which means that artists who performed at the association are not permanent.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have VISA/Mastercard, please contact our team member, Phahuor at 010816040.

If you already donate or just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Please make this louder by sharing to other people you know. Please keep this movement going. 

This is an investment on artist and art. It's not just an normal donation. 

Your contribution will not only save the Sbek Thom Theater, but also spread loves and encouragement to every artists in Cambodia. 

Thank you!

Or-Kun

#5KRiels: For the Life of Cambodian Shadow Puppet?
5000 Riels (1.25 dollars) for the life of Cambodian Shadow
Puppet, basically know as Sbek Thom in Cambodian language, is projected with
the purposes of preserving, enhancing the quality and most importantly
inspiring the younger generation about the Sbek Thom Theater.
5000 Riels for Sbek Thom was born right after we had heard
the saddest news that Mr. Mann Kosal, known as master of L’khon Sbek and the
founder of Sovannaphum Arts Association planned to change his career from the
theater director to the Tuk-Tuk driver and settled his life in one province in
Cambodia. Our hearts dropped knowing this announcement from one of our team as
we highly respect his talents, commitments and sacrifices through years to come
to this point, and most importantly, as Cambodians, we could not let this world
art heritage – Puppet Shadow Theater die and leave nothing for the next
generation. 
The theater is performed every Friday and Saturday at the
association; the number of both local and international audiences decrease from
one week to another because of the lack of human resource in operating,
managing and marketing both performances and the association. With no supports
from neither government, public nor any NGOs, Master Kosal have been struggling
years and years in balancing the income and expenses until these recent days
that he was totally hopeless in carry on his dream. 
The only inspiration holding on him to go through all
obstacles over years is to see the next generation knows and loves Sbek Thom
Theater and to make sure that it is well preserved. Fight alone, he will not be
able to accomplish, but fight together will do. 
Without
Sovannaphum theatre, there will be no Sbek Thom. As Sbek Thom now is in crisis,
only people like you will help us to achieve this goal by sustain this
performance art into life.

story:
I’m Ken Ashton,  a Washington, DC. based photographic artist.

I’ve been making pictures of DC and the north east for over 25 years. I have a book project called   Portsmouth: collected Saturdays. Portsmouth, Ohio is a small city on the Ohio River on the other side of Appalachia. For the last 6 years I’ve been photographing the neighborhoods of Portsmouth. I've been drawn to capture the vibe of this river town as my latest investigation of urban landscape, revealing  the legacy of the cost deindustrialization has impacted on countless cities in the U.S., and Portsmouth was no different. The introduction by Paul Roth and the essay by Kriston Capps,  will offer knowledgeable information on Portsmouth as well as the subject matter behind the images.

With your help, this cohesive body of work will be my first monograph of images produced for the world wide public.

Portsmouth  will be published by Daylight books a non-profit organization dedicated to publishing art and photography books. The cost of production includes the design by an award winning designer Ursula Damm, printing and distribution.

The Perks

The Perks include Postcards, Books and Prints in various sizes. 

All signed by the Artist.


Please share this Funding Campaign 

Email, Text, Tweet, and share on Facebook by using the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
PARK(ing) Day: The Book


We never thought it would go this far!

This year, 2016, is the 10th Anniversary of PARK(ing) Day, the annual worldwide event where artists, designers and citizens transform metered parking spots into temporary public parks. Over the ten years of a PARK(ing) Day, we have seen thousands of PARK installations in hundreds of cities around the world, and the event inspired the creation of a new type of urban space: the parklet.

After a decade of parks in parking spaces, it’s the perfect time to develop and publish a book that encapsulates the project, its beginnings, development, expansion, impact and legacy.
 

Help us make this a reality!

We are seeking funding to gather images from participants around the world, commission essays, and assemble PARK(ing) Day materials into a book that is both visually compelling and critically rich. Great for the coffee table or the home library!

We need your support to lift the book project off the ground!


What We Need & What You Get

In this initial fundraising campaign, we need your support to get the project started! Funds will be used to gather and curate images and stories, commission essays, design the book.

At this point, the plan is to self-publish the volume (but if you work at a publishing house and are interested, we’d love to hear from you!)

Plus, you get a chance to own some pieces of PARK(ing) Day history, including T-shirts, limited edition fine art prints and custom made art books!

 

 

The Impact

The impact of PARK(ing) Day – unintended as it was at the beginning – is still unfolding around the world. The project continues to inspire critical dialog around the use of urban public space, and has inspired the creation of parklets – small, permitted public plazas in parking spaces. Parklet programs continue to proliferate around the United States and the world,
 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Contribute your images and stories!
    We will be asking PARK(ing) Day participants to submit images and short stories for inclusion in the book. More on that in the fall, after PARK(ing) Day 2016.
  • Help us spread the word about this project! Share, blog, repost far and wide!

Thank you!

story:
My Campaign and Why It’s Important

Over the past few years I have become extremely successful.  Helping and supporting a wealth of businesses to get off the ground, expand and grow, has been both rewarding and challenging.  I have achieved this by developing strong corporate logo’s that define company images.  Having a strong identity, in this competitive world, is important to both my clients and I.

What Contributors will Help Us Achieve?

However, I now want to develop and grow my Online Website Graphic Design business.  This will allow me to help even more businesses grow and develop. As a result, I will be able to employ a wealth of people with numerous skills from website designers, graphic designers to content and copywriters.

Contributors will help me to achieve a successful, professional business that people will recommend to their business colleagues and friends.  My brand will have integrity and will achieve its vision of developing a strong Online Website service.

What We Need and What You Get

Funding

The funding required to set up the business will be $25000.  It is broken down as follows:

10% for cash flow and reserves

20% for salaries for web and graphic designers and content writers and renting office space

20% for marketing my campaign and advertisements

30% for building assets for various websites

20% for creativity development projects

Where the funds will go if I don’t achieve my goal

My project proposal is robust.  I have numerous leads and contacts, and have started to establish trusted relationships with lots of different successful business people, who are going to help support and give me advice. 

In the unlikely event that the project would fail, then the money will be invested in office space, for young entrepreneurs, who have similar goals and ambitions.  I will then invest my time and energy helping them to achieve their dream and will work tirelessly to strive as one team, to achieve our overall goal.

The Impact

Why this project is valuable?

The project is a benefit, as it will provide experience to small business owners and starts ups.  These types of businesses can sometimes find it difficult to get their business off the ground. 

The usual reason for this is that to conduct business in certain arena’s such as a graphic designer or a website designer you need a portfolio.  If you don’t have a portfolio, because you are just starting out, it’s not always that easy to get your first break.  This project will help support these people as I am a relatively new start up business myself although I have built up a great deal of knowledge and experience in a short space of time.

My Successful Track Record

I have completed numerous projects.  Some of my work can be found under the following links:

https://www.peopleperhour.com/freelancer/abbas/creative-senior-designer/776452

https://www.facebook.com/CartoonizeMePk/

Risks and Challenges

What Qualifies Me To Overcome Hurdles

I am a confident, passionate and driven individual.  At times it will be tough and I am not naïve to this fact.  I know I will have to work hard and keep going even in the face of adversity. I believe that if I surround myself with a great team and engage them, then we can deliver a sound business plan, and support and encourage others to do the same.

Describe Your Plan for Solving These Challenges

My plan is to review the process every week and see what strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and business threats there are.  I will celebrate success when we have accomplished tasks.

I will then communicate this to my team and we will overcome any challenges with a clearly defined strategy, for any problems we encounter.

Other Ways You Can Help

I will tell people about the benefits of my campaign.  Not everyone will have the resources to help financially.  However, from my experience networking and talking to others is a great way to spread the word about my brand.  Of course, sharing the Indiegogo tools will be invaluable in developing my business.  I look forward to your support and I am certain I will build up a great network of people some of whom may even be invaluable to you.

https://www.facebook.com/CartoonizeMePk/
Risks and
Challenges
What Qualifies
Me To Overcome Hurdles
I am a confident, passionate and driven individual.  At times it will be tough and I am not naïve
to this fact.  I know I will have to work
hard and keep going even in the face of adversity. I believe that if I surround
myself with a great team and engage them, then we can deliver a sound business
plan, and support and encourage others to do the same.
Describe Your
Plan for Solving These Challenges
My plan is to review the process every week and see
what strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and business threats there are.  I will celebrate success when we have
accomplished tasks.
I will then communicate this to my team and we will
overcome any challenges with a clearly defined strategy, for any problems we
encounter.
Other Ways You
Can Help
I will tell people about the benefits of my campaign.  Not everyone will have the resources to help
financially.  However, from my experience
networking and talking to others is a great way to spread the word about my
brand.  Of course, sharing the Indiegogo
tools will be invaluable in developing my business.  I look forward to your support and I am
certain I will build up a great network of people some of whom may even be
invaluable to you.

story:
Hi there! We are four artists from Paphos Cyprus, which is here:


The Kimonos Art Center is a project we started dreaming of a while ago. The idea is, no more, no less, to create an art school in a place where it is much needed.

But first of all, let's meet the crew: 

 

With a little bit of luck, lots of patience and plenty of good will we started working this summer, renovating the old house of Charalambos' grandparents to transform it to a fully equipped art studio where we could work, teach, give lectures, invite people for workshops, create a residency program for art students and artists from abroad... and to have a nice place to sit back and drink coffee and beer during the nice warm Cyprus evenings.

In the Kimonos Art Center we will have studios for drawing, painting, printmaking, photography, DSLR filmmaking, animated filmmaking, video art and cementography (a Cypriot technique that we currently are the only place on earth to teach). 

All four of us combined can do great stuff.


For more details you can visit our website at kimonosartcenter.com. That's the one Sylvia created and it's awesome. 

What we need  from you is, of course, the money to do so.

What has been already done (and needs to be paid for): 

We have scrubbed, cleaned, repaired and painted all the walls, doors and windows of the house. We have demolished two walls to create two large spaces, one for the painting and drawing studio and one for the photography, video art, and DSLR filmmaking studio, which will be used at the same time as a library. We have replaced and fixed the electrical installation and the plumbing. We have moved all of our separate stuff in the house. And landscaped the garden. 


What needs to be done:

We need to renovate the auxiliary building behind the house which will be transformed into a guesthouse, in order to be able to welcome visitors for the residency program. This includes replacing doors and windows, repairing the plumbing, fixing the electrical installation, making a roof (!) for our kitchen, buying the furniture and the electrical appliances. We do all the work ourselves (with the help of our relatives and friends who have probably started regretting having met us in the first place) but the expenses for all the materials for the renovation are still considerable. And, we also need to pay for the equipment we do not have yet: we will build our own printing press (buying one is too expensive, if we take in consideration the shipping fees), we have to buy a projector for our screenings and for our lectures, we need computers for all the digital technique classes (photography, DSLR filmmaking, video art, animated filmmaking and new media) and we really need some furniture: bookshelves, tables, working benches, desks and some new chairs while we are at it. 

 We need you in order to be able to do all these.

What's in it for you:

Since most of you probably don't live on Cyprus and do not have anything immediate to gain from us creating this art center, what we offer as perks is our own art. You can see what you can get for funding us in the perks list and you should check out our Gallery to get an idea of what we are offering. 

If you live near by you are welcome to visit us. 

The names of all those who participate, no matter how much you offer, will be written on the school's main entrance wall, our Great Wall of Sponsors. 

A part from all these amazing perks, the most precious one is our eternal gratitude and the importance of participating in something that we promise will last and that will give birth to beautiful art works, become the starting point for many artists, a center of creation and an inspiring place for lots of people.


You can help even if you have no money!

If you feel for us, if you believe in what we are trying to accomplish and you wish to help but have no money, you can still help by spreading out the word. Tell your friends, your family, your coworkers and anyone who might be interested in helping us out. You can do so by using the Indiegogo share tools on Facebook and Twitter, or by just telling people around you in the real world.

story:
*********************** THE PROJECT ************************

The City of Lost Angels memorial & What’s Working is Broken album are currently touring as a multi-media installation that is being seen in galleries, schools and street corners across the country, engaging other artists, organizers and community members along the way.  Funding this project will allow us to bring the installation to more cities, complete this powerful album and continue documenting personal testimonials of those impacted by police violence and the system. 

CITY OF LOST ANGELS is a memorial to loved ones who have been killed by police or street violence, and those that have been lost through incarceration and deportation.  Over the past 10 years, Kim McGill, an organizer with the Youth Justice Coalition (YJC), has worked with young people in juvenile halls, youth prisons, high schools and community centers to create these memorial plaques. 

WHAT’S WORKING IS BROKEN is an album composed by Veronique d’Entremont of recordings made during YJC protests and organizing against LAPD violence, and personal testimonials of police abuse.  It is an audio experience that integrates personal stories, radio journalism and music.  YJC youth leaders Malik Brock, Ronnie Dunmore and Jose Gallegos have joined this project to work on new tracks and bring it to the streets as a tool to engage people in conversation and action to expose and end police violence. 

Together we are using this project to educate, inspire action, build connections and promote understanding between communities, and to support the Youth Justice Coalition's organizing led by youth and communities most impacted by police violence, including the families of more than 630 people killed by law enforcement in LA County since 2000.


************ This project has EXPANDED and continues to grow ************


We’re still working on NEW TRACKS for the final album, but current tracks are available to listen to at www.whatsworkingisbroken.com 

ALBUM: We want this album to sound as powerful as the stories contained in it, and for the booklet to be informative and beautiful.  $2000 to get the album mastered and to print 500 copies of the CD and artist booklet. 

MEMORIAL: The memorial is composed of over one-hundred handmade paper “tiles” that are arranged like bricks on a wall.  We want to scan these, print them on canvas and sew them into a large quilt/tapestry.  This version can be hung easily for street installations and we won’t have to risk damaging the original memorial. Sadly, people across this country continue to lose their lives to violence on the street, by the police, and through the system.  Additional canvas memorial squares can be created by community members and added to in every city. This will cost us about $1500 in printing and materials. 

RECORDING: An important part of this project has been documenting the personal testimonials of people who have experienced police violence.  Traveling to other cities with the memorial had granted us the opportunity to learn more about current and past incidents of police terror.  In Baltimore, we heard from many residents that the police have refused to respond to 911 calls since the murder of Freddie Gray, and subsequent uprising.  In West Philadelphia, we met residents whose homes were destroyed in the 1985 police firebombing of the MOVE headquarters, and heard about the city's attempts to erase this history.  These are stories that are not being told in the mainstream media, and we hope to continue documenting them to bring them to light.

If we don’t meet our goal, we’ll scale back number of CD’s we’re printing, the length of the artist booklet and the number of memorial “tiles” we’re having printed on canvass.  However we believe that with the support of politically and artistically like-minded folks, we can far surpass our goal.


************************ THE IMPACT ************************

The City of Lost Angels memorial was installed in Los Angeles for the first time in 2014, through a collaboration between Kim McGill, Veronique d’Entremont and Aloni Bonilla and since has been installed in galleries, schools and street corners with What’s Working is Broken to create a powerful audio-visual experience that engages viewers and people passing by. When we install on the street, this creates an opportunity for dialogue, healing and also an opportunity to document additional testimonials of police violence and harassment from people who stop to engage with the memorial.

The Youth Justice Coalition (YJC) is working to build a youth, family and prisoner-led movement to challenge Los Angeles’ California’s and the nation’s addiction to incarceration, and race, gender and class inequality throughout the juvenile and criminal injustice systems. We mobilize youth inside lock-ups, in continuation, Probation and under-resourced schools, and on the street.  Through transformative justice and community intervention/peacebuilding, direct action organizing, advocacy, political education, and activist arts, YJC works to expose and pressure the people in charge, in order to upset power and bring about change.  In 2007, the YJC founded FREE L.A. School, to eliminate barriers for system involved youth who have been pushed out of LAUSD schools.  Both Ronnie and Jose are graduates of the FREE LA high school and Veronique has taught there.  All profit from album sales will go toward supporting the Youth Justice Coalition’s work in the community.

************************ Other Ways You Can Help ************************

Other Ways You Can Help

Listen to the tracks that are available now: https://soundcloud.com/whats-working-is-broken

Watch the amazing documentary Kayla Moon created about  this project and the work of YJC: https://youtu.be/dl9aTxF7o3Q

Invite us to install the memorial in your city: whatsworkingisbroken@gmail.com

Please tell others about this project : www.whatsworkingisbroken.com

In addition to financial and promotional support, our work could greatly benefit from help of artists, organizers and others who want to participate.  Please contact us if you want to get involved.  We are also looking for people willing to donate studio time, audio engineering or printing services, or host us in cities we are visiting or traveling through.

story:
If you have ever tried to make call in a windy weather or while biking you know it is annoying. The wind noise makes it very difficult for others to hear what you are saying. Windmic provides a solution and allows you to connect with people even when the wind blows heavily when you are on the move.

Phone calls are disrupted every day because of the wind noise. Now for the first time we have a solution for you: Windmic - the wind noise killer.



Windmic in action


Technology (patent pending)


Material

Polyurethane material is optimized to block the wind but lets the sound through. The soft polyurethane material also allows you to operate the controls (volume/accept/end call).

Installation

Easy installation for almost any type of handsfree mic. Two different sizes fit most of the models.

Measurements

WIndmic comes in 2 different sizes that fit most of the handsfree mics on the market. Please check the diameter of the handsfree mic before ordering. 

Windmic story

The idea of Windmic was born while innovative entrepreneur Heikki Leskelä was biking to his favorite Yoga lesson. On the way he received an important business call and had to stop to take it. Even though the call was a success, he ended up missing the Yoga lesson. Realizing this he decided to find a solution for the problem many of us run into: - We can not really speak on a phone while it is windy outside or we are biking or doing any outdoor activities in windy conditions.



Since the initial idea Heikki gathered a team that has worked hard over the past year to bring Windmic to life. A huge amount of brainstorming, research and testing has been done to find a perfect material and design to reach the best possible solution. The team has studied different production methods to develop a product that will efficiently:

  • Eliminate the wind noise from the microphone

  • That is suitable for the most of hands-free headphones

  • That is easy to install and use

  • That is affordable to manufacture

Perks

Early bird Windmic Beta. Limited number of first ever Windmics that are handmade.


Windmic Basic Pack. Includes two Windmics for two different sized handsfree mics.


Windmic Couple Pack. Includes two large and two small Windmics for different sized handsfree mics.


Windmic Custom Fitted with premium quality RunningBass headphones.

Bluebiit RunningBass headphones fit perfectly. The looping structure guarantees comfortable fit in situations that other headphones would be unusable. Try them with helmets, headgear or safety gear!

RunningBass is equipped with a top quality handsfree mic so you can keep connected during the exercise. Ergonomic remote control enables answering or controlling playback of music without having to reach out for your phone.


What We Need & What You Get

In the world of gigantic corporations we are a small player with a great product. With a little help from you we are hoping to introduce Windmic across the globe. In order to start a company and true mass production and introduce new colors and designs we need your help.

First batch of the Windmics will be business-grey. We hope that in the future Windmics will come out with the most of the trendy colors. With  your help, we can start designing the next generation windmics with new innovative and stylish fabrics.
In return you will get a high quality simple innovation that will solve your problem of not being able to speak while on a go. You do not have to stop to make a call. Or you do not have to excuse yourself for speaking so harsh conditions that your opponent will not hear you properly. Best of all, you will not have to miss any more calls, because maybe just the next call is the most important of your life.

Timeline


Who are we?
Heikki is a long term entrepreneur with many different innovations under his sleeve. He has an extensive background in startup & IT sector with some big exits (and some craters;). He is a very positive person and he always thinks the best of people.
Jarno is a young bright designer/engineer that has helped Heikki to design and make  Windmic become a real product.
Sulevi is a seasoned product manager & marketing professional who has launched many innovative products to worldwide market. He has been a big part of making Windmic the actual product that it is today. He is also your go-to-guy in all sales, PR & marketing related inquiries.
Teppo is a long term entrepreneur whose speciality is sales and marketing. He has found many small companies and knows what it takes to make a business running. Teppo has founded a mobile software company, business gift company, marketing agency and also the biggest ski magazine nowadays in Finland.

Risks & Challenges

Windmic is basically a no-risk product. We will produce and ship them regardless of the amount of money raised. If the goal is not reached we will manufacture just enough products to ship to everyone that has contributed in the campaign - and hope they will spread the word of our product.


Now tested and proved in frosty and windy conditions in Lapland Finland!

- Works perfectly. The wind was blowing very hard and I could still have clar and proper conversation with my fiancé from the mountains, A.V.

story:
Did you miss your chance to register or donate?

Visit AirigamiAdventure.com to find out how you can still support or to register as a crew member for this amazing project!

Did you know...

Last year over 10 million Americans wanted to attend an art event, but weren't able to, simply because of the cost.

We believe art is a luxury everyone should be able to enjoy! 


What we're going to do with your support:

We're going to build the Airigami Balloon Adventure: Journey on the Genesee. It's a 5-story balloon sculpture that captures the essence of the Genesee region using tens of thousands of balloons- and it's open to the public for FREE.

We have created two other mega-sculptures over the last two years at the Sibley Building in Rochester, NY under the name "Balloon Manor". This year we're changing the name to better fit what the project has evolved into. 


Who are you guys?

We’re a group of artists from Rochester, NY, working collectively under the Airigami name, who specialize in making ginormous & awesome sculptures entirely out of balloons. You might know the principals, Larry Moss and Kelly Cheatle, from our previous (and successfully delivered) crowd-funded projects, Once Upon a Time and The Very Tall Tale of Jack and His Beanstalk, or may have seen some of our projects making the rounds on the web. 


Want to know more about us and our big projects? Maybe this video will help...

This piece was created to document our 2014 crowdfunded project The Very Tall Tale of Jack and His Beanstalk. The Airigami Balloon Adventure we are building this January is similar in scale and will occupy the same space.

This year, we're again going to transform the open atrium of the Sibley Building into a whole new world to explore. We'll be inviting people from far and wide to come in from the cold and journey through a springtime forest filled with local animal and plant life. 

This free, family-friendly event will also be educational. Artists and designers will be working with the Seneca Park Zoo to illustrate the biodiversity of our region. 


You should back this project because...

Above all else, your contribution results in the creation and free public display of the Airigami Balloon Adventure. 

To thank you for helping us keep art accessible to all, we have some unique perks we'd like to offer you. They range from a simple thank you, all the way up to spots on the crew and benefactor/corporate sponsorships.

NOTE: If you are interested in becoming a benefactor or in higher level sponsorship- ($1k and up) please contact us so that we can tailor marketing opportunities and thank you properly.


Perks


Where's the money going?

This giant community art project is for all of the public to enjoy, free of charge. However, there are a bunch of things things we still need to pay for. We’ve set a low goal to cover the bare essentials, but we’re hoping, with your help, to become an Indiegogo dream story.

Project costs include:

  • Balloons
  • Location rental 
  • Security 
  • Rigging equipment 
  • Hotel costs for out-of-town staff members 
  • Room scholarships for a few crew members 
  • Artist fees. Aside from the many hours that the two of us will put into this by the time it's completed, there are a number of key crew members that will also be putting an enormous amount of time into the project. 
  • Advertising, marketing and promotion costs

What other funding is the project receiving?

The goal we've set on this project is only a small portion of the overall cost of a project this large. We are so happy this year to be working with two wonderful local organizations that are providing financial support and other assistance. The Seneca Park Zoo Society and the YMCA of Greater Rochester are helping to make this not just fun, but also educational. The Pioneer Balloon Company, makers of Qualatex balloons, are also helping to ensure we have the building materials we need. Even as this campaign is running, we're looking for additional external support.


How many people are on the crew?

The size of the crew will depend on the amount of funding we receive, in part because the crew will come from our backers, but also because the funding we receive will determine how large this project can grow. In the past, we've had up to 450 people, including artists, technical staff and members of the local community take part in construction. 


Key team members responsible for bringing this project to you:

Larry Moss - Creative Director, Airigami
Kelly Cheatle - Artistic Director, Airigami

Suzanne Haring - Artist Wrangler
Richard Hughson - MacGyver
Michael Hardy - Sponsorship Director
Lanna Lee Maheux - Social Media Maven
Todd Neufeld
Lisa McIntire
Drew Ripley
Brian Asman


Can I be on the crew?

Yes! Please become a backer of this project. At this time, the only way we are adding crew members is through this Indiegogo campaign.


Do I have to be on the crew if I become a backer at $100 or higher?

Nope! The invitation to participate is there as an extra way for us to connect to members of the community that wish to take part.


Can I come and see the sculpture?

Yes, please do! The Airigami Balloon Adventure will be on public display for FREE January 29 - February 7 at the Sibley Building, 250 East Main Street, Rochester, NY 14604. You can even come and watch us as we build it January 25-28. If you have the means, please contribute so everyone can enjoy this work. See the event schedule for more details.


What happens to the sculpture at the end of the run?

This sculpture will be built using compostable latex balloons. At the end of the public exhibition we will have a Popping Party to take down the sculpture. (Please note, the popping party is a ticketed event.) During the popping party, everyone takes turns to pop balloons in a controlled environment. We provide the safe popping tools giving everyone an enjoyable and fair chance to find prizes hidden within the tens of thousands of balloons. 

What's the environmental impact of a five story balloon sculpture?

While tens of thousands of balloons are quite a few balloons, keep in mind that most of the volume of the sculpture will actually be filled with air. All of the balloons used in this sculpture fit on a single shipping pallet. Likewise, once popped, the balloons will return to their initial uninflated size. So around 200 pounds of popped balloons will remain at the conclusion of the event.


But garbage is garbage, right? 

Indeed. That's why we care so much about what material we use. Airigami creations are primarily made with latex balloons. Latex is a natural product derived from trees and is biodegradable. The production of latex is a natural process of many plants, and tapping of the trees does not harm them. Latex harvesting discourages deforestation because latex-producing trees are left intact. A tree can produce latex for up to 40 years. Balloons are a great product for creating big impact with a small ecological footprint.


Risks and challenges in completing this project

Constructing something large with balloons requires that everything be built at the last minute prior to displaying it. Years of experience has made it possible for us to build to something of this magnitude with reasonable certainty that it will be completed as we desire. 


Possible Challenges:

• equipment failure - We have a mechanic on our crew, RIchard Hughson, that carries the title of MacGyver. To date, we've never had a structure or piece of equipment fail that he hasn't been able to get working.

• damaged product - The folks that make Qualatex balloons have always stood by their product. It's a really good product that we use for a reason. Problems with it are rare, in our experience. However, things happen. Whenever we've needed more balloons due to unforeseen circumstances, they've always found ways of getting materials to us in time to complete a project.

• human error - Oh, no! An artist misread the plan and made twice as many of one piece, and doesn't have enough balloons for the rest! We're a creative team, and this is an art project. What's important is that the final piece looks amazing. We are flexible, and design challenges can lead to unexpected discoveries. It's all in how you look at it!


Wow, you're still reading all of this?  You must really be interested in the project. That's awesome! Why don't you scroll back up to the top of the page and back the project? Be sure to tell your friends too. We want to reach as many people as possible to attend the event. Your gift is amplified with every share!

THANK YOU!!

It's a 5-story balloon sculpture that captures the essence of the Genesee region using tens of thousands of balloons- and it's open to the public for FREE.We have created two other mega-sculptures over the last two years at the Sibley Building in Rochester, NY under the name "Balloon Manor". This year we're changing the name to better fit what the project has evolved into. Who are you guys?We’re a group of artists from Rochester, NY, working collectively under the Airigami name, who specialize in making ginormous & awesome sculptures entirely out of balloons. This year, we're again going to transform the open atrium of the Sibley Building into a whole new world to explore. We'll be inviting people from far and wide to come in from the cold and journey through a springtime forest filled with local animal and plant life. This free, family-friendly event will also be educational. Artists and designers will be working with the Seneca Park Zoo to illustrate the biodiversity of our region. You should back this project because...Above all else, your contribution results in the creation and free public display of the Airigami Balloon Adventure. To thank you for helping us keep art accessible to all, we have some unique perks we'd like to offer you. story:
We are OSlam, Oberlin College's slam poetry team and club. We believe in the word, the heart, and the beat. We need your help.

We are a group of poets with incredible stories, and we want to share them with the world. 

  • The OSlam team is a group of rowdy, soul pumping, earth shaking poets with exceptional skills and experience in slam and spoken word poetry. 
  • CUPSI, aka the College Union Poetry Slam Invitational,is the superbowl of college slamming, It is the the world's largest  and only collegiate level poetry slam, and this year, it's being hosted in University of Austin, Texas. 
  • CUPSI is OSlam's one opportunity of the year to engage in a worldwide poetry slam. The opportunities at CUPSI for young poets like us are incredible. 
  • Last year, OSlam made it to semi-finals at CUPSI 2015, placing 16th out of 65 schools. We are growing, and we need your help to push further. 
  • With your help, OSlam will be able to bring our entire team to CUPSI, and show the world what we can do. 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

We've got poems. You've got Money. Let's make a deal.

  • We'll break this down rules-of-poetry-slam style.

    Rule #1: Slams cost money.

    National poetry events are an amazing experience: they're like an athletic conference for poets. They bring out teams from across the world for a few nights, and have endless special events, super-famous featured poets hanging around, and require a whole lot of organization and event space. CUPSI is no exception; between April 6th and April 9th, some sixty teams/three hundred-odd poets will be going at it for the glory. As a result, slams like CUPSI cost a lot to attend, and we're sending sixteen poets.  The team will have to pay:

    • $1,300 for registration
    • $6,000 for transporting our 16 members between Ohio and Texas
    • $2,200 for four days food and lodging

    For a grand total of $9,500! We know that's no small sum, and we can't pay it by ourselves because:

    Rule #2: (Student) Poets are broke.

    These poets are paying for school, books, and living expenses, while making next to no money. And right now, getting money from Oberlin is difficult. Oberlin College is one of the most expensive schools in the country, and many of the poets on our team are low income. We're doing what we can to collect donations, but to get most of the money, we need you!

    Rule #3: People love poetry!

    Nuts to "a dying art form," we're cultivating a community of writers that thrives on free speech! Where poets put their stories forward in ways that enlighten all of our lives! Where free expression is transformed into freedom from oppression! Where hard truths are spoken loudly for the world to hear!! The world needs more poetry, and this cannot happen without you!!!

    But if that's not enough incentive, we have some fantastic rewards for your donations:

    • Team chapbook! Once CUPSI is through, the best work from the team's poems (!!including group pieces!!) will be anthologized in a limited edition chapbook, one of the owners of which will be you!
    • Poem postcards! Get a gorgeous postcard featuring some of the work the team produces on the road to CUPSI; some poignant lines to make your heart swell or break that you can keep on your refrigerator forever!
    • Team merch! On top of a chapbook and postcard, especially generous donors will receive one of our limited editions OSlam t shirts and sweatshirts, designed by OSlam members themselves.
    • Our undying love! Seriously this can't happen without you and every donation counts! We won't forget how much your love of poetry helped bring this team national!

    The Oomph

    Sending this team to CUPSI is a part of the larger goal of building up OSlam so that the students of Oberlin College can have a stage to speak their truths, and to learn to engage with their lives and the world in new ways by speaking to one another. Our immediate goals for this team include: 

    • Building these poets. Being on a poetry slam team is a chance for our poets to hone their skills and to grow and develop as writers. It's a chance for them to be challenged to experiment with new language and to learn to say things no one has ever said before! We want to invest in sending this amazing work, but also:
    • Bringing the poetry back home. Once these poets have had a chance to develop their work, they can come home and put their energy and their fire back into the community, and inspire the next wave of writers through writing together and sharing their skills!
    • Continuing the stories. This team is one of what we we hope will be many generations of Oberlin slam teams that aim to show the world the creativity and insight that being a student at Oberlin College truly means. 

    Risks? Challenges? Pff.

    This is not a question. This team IS going to CUPSI this year. The poets have the dedication. We've got the fire. There will be so many hours of work put into poetry over the next months, and like last year, the team WILL crush it at the competition.

    The only real obstacle is money, and that really depends on you! Please, please help us reach our goal!!!

    Community means pitching in, whatever way you can!

    We know not everyone can give money. We're college students too (though we hope you can at least chip in a buck or two!) But if you can't, here are some ways that you can help and get involved:

    • Please spread the word! We need as many people to see this as possible to meet our goal, so please share this with everyone you know!! Heck, even email it to your parents: "hey, can we help send my friends to a poetry slam?" *bambi eyes*  Check out the indiegogo share tools!
    • Other ideas? If you have some other skill you'd like to contribute to the team, run it by us! We'd love whatever help you can offer! 
    HELP US GET TO CUPSI!!! DONATE AND SHARE!!! WE LOVE YOU!!!Check out our website for more information www.oslampoetry.com

Community means pitching in, whatever way you can!
We know not everyone can give money. We're college students too (though we hope you can at least chip in a buck or two!) But if you can't, here are some ways that you can help and get involved:


Please spread the word! We need as many people to see this as possible to meet our goal, so please share this with everyone you know!! Heck, even email it to your parents: "hey, can we help send my friends to a poetry slam?" *bambi eyes*  Check out the indiegogo share tools!

Other ideas? If you have some other skill you'd like to contribute to the team, run it by us! We'd love whatever help you can offer!

story:
We need you! To help weary citizens!

All of our benches are getting a full overhaul. We want to make the playa more accessible for disabled and tired citizens. And we want it to be a comfortable and beautiful experience.

 

Money raised will go into the travel, lights and batteries, and upkeep of the benches.

story:
A Little About Lily 

 

I've been charged with a great honor and responsibility: supporting the artistic growth of my amazingly gifted child.  I recently found an outstanding, highly-recommended art studio to nurture her budding talent - just as our living expenses increased dramatically. As a single mother it's challenging to simply make ends meet, and in order to provide my daughter with the arts education she deserves, I'm reaching out to her "public." 

Many of you are already fans of her work through the photos I share on Facebook - at 8 years of age, she's already bringing people joy through her drawings. With my own past in the performing arts, I know firsthand how vital it is to nurture talent in children, and I'm determined to make this happen for Lily even if my own individual means are financially limited. 

Lori Ryland's studio is geared to not only help students develop their technique, but to prepare them for a life in art. With her guidance, they have gallery shows, develop their portfolios, and even sell prints of their work. In the future, she can even help with applying for scholarships to art colleges, should they choose to go that route. Excellent art instructors deserve to be compensated well for their skills, and while her tuition is not 'cheap,' I'm sure it's a bargain considering its worth as a whole. 

If you've been moved by, amused by, or have otherwise enjoyed Lily's efforts in the past, I hope you'll consider pitching in a little bit (seriously, no amount is too small) to help her blossom. I cannot WAIT to see what she'll be doing in 5, 10, 15 years and beyond - it may be the mom in me talking, but I truly believe she has the potential to contribute incredible things to the world. Thank you for considering a contribution!

story:
Short summary: We are The Young Quill, a fresh theatrical company, founded by six students. The Young Quill aims to stage, encourage and promote work by young playwrights, actors and practitioners around the UK. Our first project sees us travellling to four cities: Portsmouth, Cardiff, Bath, Bristol. We will conduct Open Call in each city and one play will be chosen from that process. We will then run rehearsals with a creative and production, team in each city with local young actors for three weeks, that will include workshops with experienced actor, director and writer Evi Stamatiou. Finally, in our vision to develop as many practitioners as possible, scenes from the best of the remaining submitted plays will be filmed and uploaded on an online platform. By an online voting process the participant playwrights will get a second chance for their play to be staged. The first production will be held in October 2017. Our company functions us a non-profit, and all funding will go to towards the realization and running of the company, and it is not intended for profit. 

Vision: Our vision is to become a company that embraces  potentiality. We want to offer the opportunity to young people to develop their  in a professional yet safe environment, build a network of artists  and introduce them to the industry where they can flourish.

Timeline: The entire project will run for two years. We are starting the pre-production work in May for our first destination which is Portsmouth. The show in Portsmouth will be staged in October 2017.

What we need your help with:

While we are a new theatre company, we strongly believed that the work of artist is valuable, and deserves a fair wage. Nobody should be asked to make art for less than it is worth. Hence, we need your generous financial support to help us achieve this goal.

Some of our most pressing expenses include:

Artist Fees-We do not want to compromise artistic quality with unfair wages.

Theatre Rental- Theatres are expensive to maintain, and just as expensive to rent. We are in collaboration with New Theatre Royal in Portsmouth, who has been very kind with subsidizing the rental of theatre. However, we are still in need of funding for us to be able to pay the venue rental fees. 

Administration Costs- The reminder goes towards the other aspects of realizing this company, such as marketing and advertising costs, technical and production budgets.

THANK YOU VERY MUCH! Even a pound will make a difference!

Our first project sees us travellling to four cities: Portsmouth, Cardiff, Bath, Bristol. We will conduct Open Call in each city and one play will be chosen from that process. We will then run rehearsals with a creative and production, team in each city with local young actors for three weeks, that will include workshops with experienced actor, director and writer Evi Stamatiou. Finally, in our vision to develop as many practitioners as possible, scenes from the best of the remaining submitted plays will be filmed and uploaded on an online platform. By an online voting process the participant playwrights will get a second chance for their play to be staged. The first production will be held in October 2017. Our company functions us a non-profit, and all funding will go to towards the realization and running of the company, and it is not intended for profit. Vision: Our vision is to become a company that embraces  potentiality. We want to offer the opportunity to young people to develop their  in a professional yet safe environment, build a network of artists  and introduce them to the industry where they can flourish.Timeline: The entire project will run for two years. We are starting the pre-production work in May for our first destination which is Portsmouth. The show in Portsmouth will be staged in October 2017.What we need your help with:While we are a new theatre company, we strongly believed that the work of artist is valuable, and deserves a fair wage. Nobody should be asked to make art for less than it is worth. Hence, we need your generous financial support to help us achieve this goal.Some of our most pressing expenses include: Artist Fees-We do not want to compromise artistic quality with unfair wages.Theatre Rental- Theatres are expensive to maintain, and just as expensive to rent. We are in collaboration with New Theatre Royal in Portsmouth, who has been very kind with subsidizing the rental of theatre. However, we are still in need of funding for us to be able to pay the venue rental fees. Administration Costs- The reminder goes towards the other aspects of realizing this company, such as marketing and advertising costs, technical and production budgets.THANK YOU VERY MUCH! Even a pound will make a difference!

story:
https://jetinker25.wixsite.com/fishpainting

Please see the link above to my website so you can see pictures and paintings that I've done and will include in book.  I appreciate your time and interest!

  • My name is Julia Tanigoshi Tinker.  I am an artist and an avid outdoors-woman.  I have spent the past few years fishing the waters in southeast Alaska and painting each fish and crustacean I catch.  In order to honor my Japanese heritage, I have done each painting in the gyotaku style, watercoloring each sumi ink print on handmade rice paper.  All of these paintings and additional photographs are compiled in my book.
  • My campaign is designed to fund the last third of this book which I aim to finish this summer, 2017.  With your help, I will be able to finish my book and present it to my publisher who is awaiting its completion.
  • I invite you to join me on this last leg of this Alaskan journey!  If you have been to Alaska or dreamed of exploring the Last Frontier or just want to see its beauty, I invite you to accompany me on this artistic adventure!  After this Indiegogo campaign is finished, I will be blogging my journey from my boat in Alaska and you can watch me fish and paint every day!  I want this book to promote the conservation of Southeast Alaska's marine life and, with your help, we can make this happen!  Thank you for your support!  I don't take it lightly.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

  • $5,000 will be used to help print and publish 1,000 copies of my 75-page full color book of paintings and photographs.  $2,500 will be used for fuel, gear and painting supplies.  $1,500 will be used for packaging and shipping all perks to my supporters!
  • I hope that you will share in my excitement for this project!  I will send you gifts ranging from signed prints on rice paper for a $50 contribution to original black and white gyotaku paintings of Alaska rock fish and a signed first edition finished color book for a $500 donation.
  • If I don't reach my goal, I will still use any funds donated to help print and publish my book.  Any donation you might provide will not go unappreciated!  Thank you!!!

The Impact

  • My project is important because it allows each contributor a hand in promoting conservation of the marine life of Southeast Alaska.  Together, we can protect our Last Frontier!
  • As an artist, I have had a number of solo shows both in Alaska and in California.  My art is currently sold in galleries in Alaska and California.  As an avid outdoors-woman, I have studied the marine ecosystem in Southeast Alaska intently and can tell you what kind of fish live where and can talk to you about the life cycle of a Coho salmon, all while painting a gyotaku print of a fish I caught that same day!
  • I will be spending this summer, 2017, completing this book.  There will be sunny days when Alaska smiles on me; and there will be windy, rough days when the sea is angry and the waves go over the cabin of my boat.  Yet, each day, I will be out on the water for 8-10 hours searching for the last 15 species of fish for my book.  I invite you to watch my video blogs each day this summer as I document this journey!  Your support will help me achieve this goal!

Risks & Challenges

  • There are hurdles in this journey.  I am tenacious and optimistic by nature.  Whether I am able to find the fish each day and complete my prints and paintings each night will depend on my tenacity and hard work.  I love what I do.  I will stop at nothing.  Alaska is beautiful, but its waters can be unforgiving.  It takes a tough soul to put in the time to find each fish in waters ranging from 50 meters to 350 meters in depth.  I have captained my own boat many years and  I can't wait to get back on the waters in Alaska for this last portion of my book.   
  • Whether or not you've been on a boat, or explored Alaska, you, too, can help me complete this book!  I will keep you up to date every day with my video blogs and will send you personal emails about my progress all summer!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you aren't able to contribute, I would still really appreciate your getting the word out about my Indiegogo campaign!
  • Please share the news about my campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!

Whether or not you've been on a boat, or explored Alaska, you, too, can help me complete this book!  I will keep you up to date every day with my video blogs and will send you personal emails about my progress all summer!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute, I would still really appreciate your getting the word out about my Indiegogo campaign!
Please share the news about my campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Hi, my name is Pavia and I'm a sculptor here in Fruita, Colorado.

I build large-scale public artwork in my garage using concrete, steel, and glass.

I’ve been an artist for as long as I can remember, but last year,

I quit my day job to do it professionally.

Since then, I’ve made six life-sized sculptures

and many smaller works too. 

I'm a one-woman show - I build my sculptures from start to finish by myself,

including all the welding and metalwork.​

I designed and built my own website and web store, and I do all of my own content marketing, including graphic design work,

and filming & editing my own process videos.

My sculptures have won several awards and are on display throughout Colorado - in Grand Junction, Denver, Westminster, and soon, Longmont and Palisade. 

I’ve had some great successes, but I’m still just starting out, and nothing kills a creative mood more than worrying about how long you’ll be able to pay the bills before the money runs out.

I’ve sold some artwork and won some award money this past year,

but I’ve also spent a lot of my savings on a welder, cutting torch, and other tools and materials for my studio -

as well as basic living expenses.

I'm here on IndieGoGo today to ask for your help.

I set a goal of $20,000 for this campaign, because

that amount of money would go a REALLY long way for me, replenishing my spent-down savings and giving me at least another year or two to build up my patron base while I continue doing what I love -

MAKING ART!

And YES -

there are some awesomely artsy perks in it for you, including t-shirts,

custom illustrations,

and one-of-a-kind sculptures.

Thank you ALL for spreading the word and supporting my artistic journey -

I need YOUR help to continue creating my art!

story:
Photo ©Tetsugo Hyakutake

Social Dress New Orleans - 730 days after 10 years after

Social Dress New Orleans is the culmination of a three-month collaborative effort with local volunteers at 1941 Caffin Avenue, located in the Lower Ninth Ward neighborhood. With my team, I applied multiple layers of latex mixed with paint were applied to the exterior of a house that had been damaged by Hurricane Katrina and remained untouched in the summer of 2007. Once these latex panels dried, we peeled them off to create a textured 3-D print of the structure. I also documented the political and physical struggle to create this work on my blog, and my friend, filmmaker Ambarish Manepalli directed a documentary about the process.

I envisioned this piece as a way to make the tragedy of New Orleans tangible to those far removed from the disaster. I had lived in New Orleans from 2000-2003, the first years that I lived in the US after leaving my home country of Japan. For me, New Orleans is my US home, so to watch it being destroyed on my small TV as I unpacked from moving to New York City in August of 2005 was heart wrenching. Because of my financial situation, I couldn't visit right away, but I followed everything I could in the news, online, and in frequent phone calls with my friends who still lived there. Yet I was still unprepared for the scale of destruction that remained when I first returned in the summer of 2006. Cars were still on top of houses, and the streets had barely been cleared in certain neighborhoods a full ten months later. Yet, because the city wanted to boost the tourism market, most press outside the city discussed the successful "recovery" of areas like the French Quarter, and the only contradictory evidence that seemed available to those outside the area were these photography exhibitions featuring images of destruction so spectacular they were hard to grasp. I felt we really needed something physical, tangible, that could be taken to sites outside New Orleans to help people far from the destruction grasp the continuing reality of everyday residents in New Orleans.

Toward this end, Social Dress New Orleans was displayed as a full structure at Socrates Sculpture Park in New York City from July 2007 to March 2008 and at the Prospect.1 Biennial in New Orleans from October 2008 to January 2009. Individual components of the work were also exhibited at various venues in locations as distinct as Mobile, AL; Hamilton, NY; and Dresden, Germany, yet the opportunity to exhibit the entire house once again has not presented itself until now, a decade after it was originally cast.

Social Dress New Orleans has been included in SPRING BREAK Art Show's BKLYN IMMERSIVE, an exhibition of immersive installations and environments on view from May 6—May 14 at the City Point building in Downtown Brooklyn. With three weeks to pack, ship, and install this house-sized work, I felt it was essential to present the work again with the help of an organization like SPRING/BREAK that is good at bringing visibility and a wide-ranging audience to its events. This also felt like the right moment to reconsider the issues faced by New Orleans and the U.S. anew within the context of increased racial tensions, accelerated gentrification, and a set of national policies that parallel the ideals that led to the construction of the MRGO Canal and the flooding of the Lower Ninth Ward during Hurricane Katrina.

 

Photo ©Tetsugo Hyakutake

 

Help Preserve the Work Today and Provide for its Future

Although the work is already on view at BKLYN IMMERSIVE with the generous support of SPRING/BREAK and CITY POINT, I am thinking about how to sustain the piece after the closing of the exhibition, and to help find a place to store the work as we look for future exhibition venues.

If we can reach the full funding goal of $12,000, we can provide for the future of this project and make sure that I don't have to abandon this piece that so many people contributed to. Although I have been so fortunate that artist, Luis Colmenares, provided a home for Social Dress New Orleans these past eight years, between the cost of returning the work to New Orleans, and the difficulty of finding venues interested in showing the work when it is stored so far away from where I am based in New York, I cannot continue to store the work in New Orleans. But storage is not cheap in the New York area, and I don't currently have a space to place the work, so I also need funds to help store the work until we can find the next place to exhibit this work (otherwise I may be forced to trash it!).

For those who can donate, there are some great perks including t-shirts featuring a design pulled from the address numbers attached to the original house at 1941 Caffin Avenue, a tote bag featuring one of my first sketches of the house as it would be installed at Socrates Sculpture Park, small edition cast latex works from New Orleans, and VIP studio tours.


T-shirt design (does not represent color of shirt or color of print)

         
Tote bag design (does not represent color of bag or of print)

 

(c) SPRING/BREAK Art Show, photo by Samuel Morgan Photography

 

Why SPRING BREAK?

Although Social Dress New Orleans received a lot of press when it was created in 2007, including articles in The New York Times, the Washington Post, the AP, Art in America, and NPR's Studio 360 to name a few, without opportunities to show the work itself, it had fallen off the radar much like the lingering effects of Hurricane Katrina have fallen out of view for most of the American public. SPRING/BREAK Art Show has a history of successful events that receive coverage from major art and news press, and has featured works that go on to successful exhibitions at major art institutions. Additionally, by working at City Point which is centrally located in Downtown Brooklyn near major shopping venues, and by not charging admission, the exhibition itself is available to a wide range of visitors, including those who do not regularly visit art exhibitions. So far we have seen constant foot traffic by a real mixture of arts professionals and passersby who have never gone to an art exhibition before. This is the kind of mixed audience I hope to engage with this work.

 

Challenges

The work is already up, but the challenge is to make this exhibition opportunity a first step in reminding people about the continuing effects of Hurricane Katrina not only in New Orleans, but across the US. This means not only spreading the word about this exhibition and fundraiser as wide as possible, but building momentum and demand for the work to be shown again in prominent venues across the country. I was able to show the work in Prospect.1 because of the many local voices who asked for it to be brought down for the biennial. Now, if I can raise the funds necessary to preserve the work, this will also be a strong demonstration of support that can help me quantify to potential museums, galleries, and other exhibition venues that there is an active and interested audience for the work.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, help us get the word out and make sure Social Dress New Orleans can continue to serve as a reminder of the continuing impact of the man-made disaster that was Hurricane Katrina. Share this project on social media (using the Indiegogo sharing tools!), visit the exhibition in the remaining days (if you're in the New York area, stop by any time from Noon-7pm today through Sunday, May 14, 2017) and post images on Instagram or Facebook! Tell your friends, co-workers, and family about the project. I need your help to make sure this project gets covered and can continue to be presented!
